reviewText:
Firstable..sorry for any typos and spelling errors i made in that text. I tried to write as good as i can.

What is Deadlight?Well. It's basically a side-scrolling Platformer with a Zombie Setting. I know the market is getting overrun" by Zombie games recently. But i hope i can make you understand why THIS one is really special and diffrent. Deadlight is not a Sandbox type of Game. It's a Story driven linear Adventure and it's a damn good one. And even tho it's relativly short (took me about 4 Hours to beat) it is still worth the Money.

GameplayLet's start with the most important thing. The Gameplay. You basically run from the left side of your screen to the right side of your screen. There is Combat
date: Jumping and some Puzzling involved tho. Zombies (called "Shadows" in the world of Deadlight ) can become really dangerous once you are outnumbered. And i have to be honest here. I died more than once because i underestimated the Situation. There are Weapons in the Game. You get a Fireaxe
recommended: a Revolver and a Rifle at some point. But both guns can run out of ammunition (tho i almost never had that Problem) Shooting works actually pretty good in this Game. I played with my 360 Controller. You aim with the right stick while you shoot with the RT. That works pretty good actually. Most of the Time i spend shooting at some objects like locks and so on
hoursPlayed:
rather than Zombies.  Close Combat works ok i think. It's nothing special really. You basicly Hit B to swing your Axe around. That works pretty good for what it is and the Stamina System in the Game provents you from Hack & Slay your way thru bigger groups of Zombies. the jump mechanics also work pretty good.

StoryI have to be honest. The Story isn't that great. You play as Randy Wayne. A Canadian from B.C who is on the lookout for his Family in Seattle aswell as his friends who got caught by a Group called "The new Law". So basically the entire story is based on you finding them. It's really nothing special and we've all have seen that stuff million times in other games. It's not bad don't get me wrong. It makes sense for what it is but don't expect something majestic outta it. It won't blow your mind.

GraphicsThe Game looks good. It really does. It's not Crysis of course but it gets the job done and it definitely delivered a good atmosphere. Light effects are decent and the Levels look like the Dev's really put in some love and time. I can't complain about it.


So i recommend this Game. If you don't wanna pay 10 Bucks for it (which i think is actually a good price for this game) then just wait for a sale. But it's really worth checking out. even for people who don't like the Genre (like me for example).

i would rate Deadlight 8/10
"

reviewText: Okay, I'm writing this review because the game is currently on the cheap right now, but if you want it and miss it this time, my review will be out there for the next sale. Don't get this game unless you get it really cheap: $3-5 U.S. tops. I'm running this review off of my memories of playing the game several months ago. It definitely left an impression, so let's get on with it.\n\nI'm not writing a really long review this time. Just the basics. It's pretty simple really. Deadlight is an atmospheric side-scroller. You have obstacles in the form of environmental hazards, zombies, unfriendlies, and, of course, obstacles which you must hurdle, climb, dodge, slide past, leap, and time to avoid/survive. There is a very loose storyline that is way too predictable, so if that matters to you, you may just want to skip it. The graphics/atmosphere are actually okay for what it is. Overall the game is a pretty typical side-scrolling platformer, but there are a few pleasant surprises and only a few irritatingly, mind-numbingly, platformer-typical moments of inane aim-twitch-jerk-with-just-the-right-timing @55hat-ery/@55clown-ery. Some odd bits are thrown in for flavor, but mostly I found these elements annoying and distracting from what the game does well. It's almost a runner, somewhat parkour, somewhat zombie survival, with moments dedicated to each of these elements. Think post-apocalyptic urban Indiana Jones/ninja and you might be getting close to the feel of this game. Some elements are too trite and stereotypical to the genre, and there is very little replay value, BUT for a few hours of pleasant distraction it's decent. I recommend it; just don't spend more than what you'd pay for an okay cup of coffee and you'll be alright. And that's about what it's worth to me, a decent cup of coffee: not great, not awesome, but pleasant enough for the short time you spend with it, and it will pump you up a bit, but not too too much. And, although it should pleasantly distract you for considerably longer than that cup, at least you won't have to worry about it getting cold before you've finished with it.

reviewText:
All things considered, if you can get this game in a bundle or during a sale for <$2, I would consider picking it up.

However, there are a few caveats.

The game mechanics are unique - 2D platformer with jumping puzzles and the zombie genre, but overall can fall flat and feel repetitive. The other thing to note is that this game is VERY SHORT. Sub 4 hours for me in the campaign. The writing isn't compelling enough to warrant another playthrough, so from a purely consumer and casual perspective, would definitely limit purchasing to bargain bin pricing.

But if you're interested in game design and enjoy games for being different and not all about value of playable hours to dollars, Deadlight is not a bad way to go.

reviewText:
Deadlight - It differs from other Jump'n Run or Indie games!
You are in Seattle in the 1980s and you play as Randall Wayne! A disaster destroyed the whole life on earth and you lost your daughter Lydia and your wife Shannon. Now you have to find them...

It is a simple story: One brave father is looking for his family in the middle of a zombie-apocalypse.
BUT: the way is it presented is just...wow. Here are many positve (+/++) but also negative aspects (-)

++ the story is simple, but also touching
++ the soundtrack is just awesome
++ the atmosphere is presented in a nice way
++ the graphic is damn good for an Jump'n Run
++ breathtaking until the last minute
+ it's not easy - even frustrating
+ easy achievments (expect Hardcore Mode!)
+ 3 little mini-games which you will find in the game
+ little cutscenes in a comic style (a bit like Walking Dead")

and the negative ones...

- the controls are just horrible (but you find in)!
- the playtime is too short (4-5 hours)
- too expensive for the playtime (7€ are ok)
- better to play with a controller
- I didn't liked the end

If you like story-based Jump'n Run games with an awesome soundtrack and atmosphere and you are able to get the game in sale ------> in that case
date: I advise you to buy this piece of art! :-)\n\n8

The game is a 2.5D action platformer with some shooting and light puzzle solving. The art style is the strongest thing about this whilst I feel the length, voice acting and story could have been much better.

I completed this within 3 hours. A lot of that time was replaying parts with cheap deaths (falling buildings, sizeable hordes) as some scenes need to do remember how you died to avoid it, only to die again at the next jump, it can be frustrating at time. My major gripe with the mechanics is if you're too close to a wall, you cannot walljump and this caused me to die more than I'd like to admit. Also, jumping on to something directly above you can be quite clunky as you need to be super precise. The melee weapon and shooting feels quite good though with plenty of weight behind hits. The voice acting is sub-par all over but the main character got on my nerves and made me cringe constantly, he just did not suit the part and a lot of his acting seemed forced.

If you're into 2.5D action platformers, you will probably enjoy this and for that reason I recommend it. If you're interested due to the theme alone, I would say avoid this unless the price is right (as of writing it is £9.99). I believe I got it in a bundle, so it was a good buy for me. I would not have bought it was full price.

reviewText:
It is like the first “Prince of Persia” without time limit and with zombies. Game has three chapters, and the best one is the premier one, while the second lags the most gameplay-wise, which is overall running, parkouring and avoiding very dangerous when a few undead. There are some melee weapons and firearms, but it is not always possible to fight the horde, and ammo is often scarce.

I really liked the story with its flashbacks and dreams and little twists, though cutscenes have bad voice acting and sound is buggy and just disappears. Post-apocalypric city looks great and feels realistic.

Overall the game totally worth a play and may be a replay to find bonus contents.

reviewText: Crossing the threshold into the blighted world of Deadlight for the first time is akin to coming upon a great monument.  The exquisiteness of the visuals ropes you into a trance.  Despite the consistency and the quality of the prodigious visuals, as with all states of adjourned lucidity, reality eventually beckons and the stink from the rotting corpse known as Deadlight permeates your bodily receptors and you soon become cognizant of the malodorous game that has enveloped you.\n\nControls and game-play mechanics are inconsistent.  Sequences that are meant to be fluid concertos play like a broken piano.  Design that was meant to provide situational feedback and to ameliorate the user experience falls flat and winds up as a failed and frustrating implementation that is worthy of the term null and void.   Microsoft published this and I expected better.

reviewText:
I just finished Deadlight. Took me two days. It's a short game and never overstayed its welcome. To be honest, I could have gone for 3-4 more hours if they were diverse areas (forest, snow). It's fine as it is. FYI, KB/M feels not right with this one. Played it with my DS3 and it was just perfect.

The game puts you in the aftermath of a zombie apocalypse where you promptly get separated from your wife and daughter. The story revolves around finding them. It's a very focused affair. Don't expect any side story or even much in terms of other characters. Very to the point.

In 2.5D fashion you're fighting zombies with an axe, pistol and shotgun but don't mistake it as a true action game. Even few zombies can overwhelm you quickly. Often I found myself pushing them away and just running away to higher ground. Besides combat there is a lot platforming which is OK. Nothing spectacular as you don't do free-form jumping. There's not much to do wrong or different as intended.

The real star here is the desolate world and atmosphere. I wished throughout for an open-world game in this vibe to carefully sneak through a lost, zombie-ridden city. In that, not feeling overpowered in combat was the right decision.
The only downsides were a specific early area (Sewers) since that felt totally unrealistic and was totally different and unfitting compared to the rest of the game. Other than that, there are tidbits of aspects when society crumbles but they were never explored too much. Shame.

I liked this game a lot. Ending was great. It's short and good. Give it a try.

reviewText:
This is a pretty decent 2D platformer. The setting is in a zombie apocalypse, stale overall but kinda refreshing for a 2D platformer, the graphic is great and the art style is very nice similar to that of limbo. Control is not as tight as it could have been, sometimes the jumping can be a little bit wonky but overall serviceable. Combat is done pretty well, shooting feels like it got a lot of weight and punch. The game is pretty short and linear, there are some exploration but most of it is just go left instead of right for a bit. Story is ok, just your typical apocalypse story, nothing stand out.

One complain I have is the audio control, the volume you set for the game doesn't carry over to the cutscene so if you like to play game on low volume like me while watching something else, be prepared for random volume spike.

Overall a good 2D platformer, good for a relaxing, not too much thinking afternoon. 7/10

reviewText:
What starts of as an interesting survival platformer quickly dissolves into an absolute mess of a game by the second act, where it first strips you of the weapons you just learned to use and forces you to complete a set of extremely simple puzzles and plain annoying platforming sections. Afterwards you don't even get your stuff back, despite it thematically making sense that you would.

The visuals and initial gameplay are very well executed, but it's not enough to give this a recommendation. The quality of the voice acting is all over the place and as I said above, the second half of the game is just frustrating instead of challenging. The gun and slingshot controls are wonky to control with a mouse.

The game also starts off with 2 side-characters that you get seperated from, with no explanation of who they are, how they met or what they may have been through. When one of these characters lies dying when you find him, the game expects you to have some sort of emotional reaction. But since you know absolutely nothing about them aside from their name, you obviously don't.

So no, not recomended. The puzzles are far too simple, the platforming is tedious, the story makes little sense, characters are completely forgettable, the controls are wonky and the gameplay is inconsistent.

PS: 'Shadows' is a terrible name for zombies. I'm all for originality, but 'SHADOWS'?
If you're going to put the most cliche video game enemies in your game anyway, you're not going to redeem it by naming them anything other than 'zombies' or 'infected'.

reviewText: Deadlight has all the tools to make it a great game, beautiful graphics, fast paced platforming and exploration elements and the tension of a zombie outbreak that seems to constantly be on your tail. Unfortunately, the clunky control scheme will have you failing simple jumps, dying over simple mistakes and being ripped apart by zombies quite regularly. For a story based platformer, I didn't find myself rooting for the hero or even care about his companions, especially when each of them seems to have a shorter life expectancy than a femal black stoner in a horror film. When you finally do keep a companion alive what results is one of the most frustrating escort quests in any game, where a fast paced chase sequence" is jarringly broken over and over again while you stop to open doors or help your otherwise useless companion up ledges.\nThat's one of the fundamental problems with this game - it's poor pacing and direction. Sections where you would surely be making a quick escape are full of jarring climbing sections that you seem to take at a rather sedate pace

reviewText: Deadlight is a great little game to knock over on a weekend. It's essentially a puzzle platformer in which you have to avoid zombies and get to a safe point to meet up with your group - pretty standard zombie stuff really, but there's nothing wrong with that if it's done well and Deadlight does everything well except for voice-acting and script-writing. The motions feel fluid and nicely animated and you really get a feel for the bleak post-apocalyptic cityscape that you're traversing. The cut scenes have a nice art-style, even though they are essentially moving cut-outs with (groan-inducing) dialogue. There's a rather annoying spikey trap zone, but every good game has it's frustrating moments just to remind you that it's not all easy. Playing through Deadlight was a very pleasurable experience, and even though the dialogue was horrible I'd still recommend it. 7 out of 10, would traverse.

reviewText:
I have to say that this game was a little disappointment to me.

+ Decent graphics.
+ Nice environment.

- Bugs. (Zombies, aka Shadows falling from the map.)

I can only recommend this game if it's on sale, cause it's not worth the full price.

Remember this is just my opinion, some of my (+) can be a (-) to you and viceversa. It depends from player to player.

reviewText:
5/10

The pros:
- Great utilization of the unreal engine for platformer mechanics & immersive 3D game art
- Good game progression in terms of skill, weapons
- Good design elements - stamina affects your ability to attack and your overall strength

The cons:
- Lack luster story line, rushed ending & numerous plot holes made a game with great potential feel ordinary
- Inexperienced voiced acting and/or lack of emotion in voices was difficult to take seriously, given the games setting
- Had a very mothering game lexicon system that seemed to evaporate temporarily - making some parts very confusing

Overall:
- Good game to buy on a sale price imo, full price - would be a gamble.
- Reminded me a lot of Flashback from the good ol' snes rom days, in terms of general mechanics (However failed to do equally well on storyline & complexity of level design)

reviewText:
There are two things on everyone’s minds when it comes to zombie games. Is either going to be a delightful gore fest with pure “kill everything that moves” mechanics, or a survival low pace experience with a big world to explore and bake beans to collect. When you first see Deadlight you might think that this is not an exception if you see the post-apocalyptic setting, character layout and the zombies, but at the same time is a 2D puzzle side scrolling. But it can embrace those factors and go more than just that, taking the whole kill stuff, oh god I am being overrun, to another perspective.

The game takes place in the post-apocalyptic Seattle when the site gets invaded by zombies. The story doesn’t touch the theme of how this happen until you go to a certain location in the game, so you will mostly uncovered through collectables notes from Randall´s diary, which by the way is the guy who you will play at. He gets separated from his surviving friends after a zombie attack, being the main mission to reunite with them as well as to find his missing family that he lost track of. The plot seems solid at the beginning, as Randall progress he also encounter other threats and revelations that you might not see coming. Problem is that it gets so complicated that in the final stage of the story it all can end in a blind, you will be left with quite some doubts about why this may come to that. Above all this, story is strong enough to bring pace and for you to continue through it.

So what genre is this? Well don’t get confuse, this is still merely a 2D puzzle platform just like Limbo. The difference is that the challenge that you will encounter is how to evade the zombies (or Shadows as they call them) on each stage and that’s when the level design really shines. You are going to be moving boxes, jump fences, move through houses, electrify stuff around, climb buildings and drop buildings, in order to reach your objectives. The game take place in 3 big areas, some of them are more action packed and some more puzzle base, making the journey less repetitive than just run for zombies or move tramps. That is not only the game´s focus, you will have to kill the infected shadows allow the way if you want to reach the end of the game. Luckily Randall count with melee weapons as well as handguns and shotguns, but with limited ammo and a not very accurate combat system, it may not be a good idea to just fight your way through. Is this combination of elements between levels that make you solve how to avoid the zombies, and waste the less amount of ammo and health as possible feeling like is just the right time in the right moment (obviously since is design as a puzzle solver) without losing pace that this is an apocalyptic adventure.

Now in terms of graphics and music, you’re looking at a gorgeous game full of lights and rich art environment, using the 3d base unreal engine in combination with 2d environment, just a charm for the eye, but you will see most of the characters in black as they are simulated to look in the darkness with the sun in the far end of the map (except for the maps that are on the subway or in deep close rooms). The cut scenes are made with standard animation and a particular illustration that give essence to the invasion theme. Now all this really made the tittles game some name, but sometimes you will get confuse by the perspective and the fact that almost everything is dark (again because of the sun position). For example you may think that you can jump to a crate but really the crate is just part of the environment, since you are in one different layer, same goes for the zombies, items and platforms, they can be on your layer or on a background one.

In terms of sound the game also shines, just the right effect that you want to heard every time you slash a zombie, or shoot it, making that satisfaction gratifying for the gore fans, other sound like objects falling off the building or windows breaking give the levels the feeling that the game wants you to take it for, follow by low calm music. So overall in terms of sound and visual effects the game doesn’t let down (unless you count the lack of PC graphic settings).

So in short lines, we have a puzzle base platformer in which you survive by killing the less amounts of zombies possible or avoid them completely, with the solid objective of finding your family and uncover one or two dark little secret that kind of cause this whole mess.  Despite some perspective problems, glitches and some level design decisions (may even include tediousness of the checkpoints), you got yourself an existing survival theme platformer that will consume 4 to 6 hours. A good purchase for the survival and 2d platform fan.

You'd be playing this game just to finish it not to explore it as the surrounding is limited ; you just have to follow the story. So, im not gonna recommend this game on pc, but for console, MAYBE.

reviewText:
After a catastrophic worldwide event, the city of Seattle has been overtaken by the infected—shadows in the game, zombies to the rest of us—and you set out in search of your family as one of the few remaining survivors. If you've played The Walking Dead, then you're no doubt familiar with this very scenario.

Deadlight is a sidescrolling, survival horror platformer with plenty of zombies coming after your brains.  Armed with a hatchet and gun, you'll run, jump, climb, push crates, take the occasional zombie's head off, push more crates, and do it all over again.  Extremely simple, completely linear, demands minimal skill from the player and is very generous with checkpoints.

The game is laid out as brief stages where your completion time and collectibles found are recorded.  You may replay them at any time from the main menu to aim for 100% and better times on the leaderboards.  Cutscenes and voice acting are so cringeworthy you'll want to skip them, but the environments look great and set the scene properly.  Deadlight takes around four hours to 100%, supports gamepad, and won't impress you but is worth playing through for something quick and mindless.

reviewText:
Story driven games are fuel for all that machinery that keeps me smiling while playing. Or staring with wide open eyes when there is no aura for a smile. Deadlight doesn't make me smile or stare with awe.

Visuals are beautiful and stunning. Narrative voice is charismatic and good to listen. And zombies. And... That's it.

Mechanics is simple, way too simple. Additionally it is irritating and buggy. The story that should be another first squad player in this type of game is again too simple, boring, disappointing and I must force myself to finish it. I am not afraid, curious or sad with all that is happening in the Deadlight. And I should (and I am not any robotic creature in case you got that impression from 'machinery' thing in the very first sentence). Although ending is quite dramatic and full of tension it doesn't make up for the whole game. The same is music - I've noticed it on credits screen. And last nail: Deadlight is the worst optimized game I've played in a very long time. My fantastic ultrabook with i7 on board and hd 4000 chuckles heavily.

Lost potential, but still a unique game in its genre. Wait for a discount and give it a try. There are not many alternatives and the Deadlight kinda shines. Recommendation for that unpolished gem.

PS There are 'making of' videos available, in Extras section when you finish the game. As this is my favorite 'extra' in every game (yeah... watching other ppl working) I recommend them heartily.

reviewText:
This game is okay overall.
It looks good, and it seemed to try to do something different in the genre by mixing survival and platforming.
The platforming is pretty good most of the time, but some sections are poorly designed (forcing you to use trial-and-error for example) and the like and sometimes the controls just don't work too well. Getting over a fence can be a chore (and whille speaking of controls, use a gamepad if you can, keyboard controls are awful). Thankfully, the checkpoints are abundant so you can re-try and die faster... Unless you quit the game. Then you'll need to repeat most of the level. Cuz.
Melee combat is pretty weak. Attacking with the axe is awkward and zombies hit pretty hard and can grap you pretty quickly, making not using the pistol or shotgun against more than 2/3 zombies a madman's dream.
Regarding the firearms, the shotgun feels very underused... you get it more than halfway through the game and loose it soon afterwards, and isn't particularly useful or used in any way for the puzzles.
The puzzles you find are pretty simple too, and that feels right. They don't break the rythm of the action or platforming and are well integrated.
The story is... decent for a game like this. The main" story is predictable and simple most of the time
date: it was obvious the devs were focusing on the protagonist's past

wich most of the collectibles in the game refer to in someway. The end-twist was pretty predictable too.



So yeah

reviewText:
*First of all,i bought this game from a HumbleBundle deal,so for such a price,i recommend it,otherwise i wouldn't*
DeadLight.Deadlight is a 2D game,with pretty good graphics which is placed in 1986,where a virus got unleashed and now shadows(a.k.a. Zombies) take over the streets.The protagonist,Randal Wayne,a 33-years-old man who used to live in Hope,Canada,a town on a mountain (i guess),seeks his family,his wife and daughter after they got seperated during the shadows* outbreak.Randalbelieves they are located in the Safe Point.Safe Point is a safe place as the radio broadcast suggests.Many people have gone there,and Randal  believes that his family is one of them.
The game is short.In about 4-5 hours,the game is completed.but what do you expect from a 2D game after all?
Ok,of course playing with a controller is much better that keyboard in many games,and 2D games are one of them.Although many people complained about the controls being bad,i didn't have a problem with them.
The truth is,the game is pretty buggy.from cutscenes without sound(this is fixable,but still the developers should have updated that) to floating zombies.Plus,one of the biggest negatives of this game,is that objects confuse you.How?some of them are background,some of them are not.Imagine that you try to jump to a platform,however this platform was a background,and you fell to your death.Great Success!
So,you would ask why i would recommend this game.It Depends on the money you will give for it.I bought it pretty cheap,and it was worth it after all.of course,i DO NOT RECOMMENT IT FOR ITS ACTUAL PRICE,but if you find it in a deal,then i suggest you give it a try!

Graphics : 7,5 / 10
Gameplay : 4 / 10
Controls : 5 / 10
Story : 7 / 10
Conclusion : 5,8 / 10

Have a good day!

reviewText:
i saw it get praised quite a lot for an indie 2D platformer, in a 3D looking vibrant world. bought it today at the sale. i played through it in one sitting (no idea how long, i can last hours), which is both good and bad. it's short, but i also enjoyed it enough to play it through.
however, nothing about it makes me happy i played it. dialogue is bad, voice acting is bad, plot is complete trite, combat mechanics are ok-ish...just button mashing for the most part, and platforming was...well pretty good, but had some problems, like making you rely on trial and error too much at times. can't shoot a window from one side, don't forget to try it from behind. nothing about any of it was original in any way, nor clever or well executed.

i unlocked hardcore mode by finishing the game, but i don't care to play it again. short game with no replay value and no memorable moments at all.

it has a certain charm, the visuals use depth well, and the world does really feel populated by zombies. and they are proper zombies: individually weak, but dangerous in groups; stupid but not too stupid and all that. it's worth the time it takes to play, but you could probably spend your money better.

reviewText:
www.suchgameshame.com

Deadlight is a game that never really grasps hold of it's potential and quickly becomes a dull and ultimately forgettable platformer.

I love zombies, maybe it's the anarchist in me that wants to see a zombie Apocalypse drop by, so I could test out my survival skills... that would consist of me mostly pretending to be Daryl Dixon from the Walking Dead. I went into Deadlight with all the best intentions. I wanted to like it... I really did!

It starts out so tense, lulling you into the world. The atmosphere in the beginning was brilliant. I was invested in the dystopian Seattle, I was motivated to help my protagonist (Randall Wayne) find his family. But play past the first act and it regrettably develops into the most infuriating excuse for a platformer.

*Spoilers ahead*
Deadlight is a game that never really grasps hold of it's potential and quickly becomes a dull and ultimately forgettable platformer.

I love zombies, maybe it's the anarchist in me that wants to see a zombie Apocalypse drop by, so I could test out my survival skills... that would consist of me mostly pretending to be Daryl Dixon from the Walking Dead. I went into Deadlight with all the best intentions. I wanted to like it... I really did!

It starts out so tense, lulling you into the world. The atmosphere in the beginning was brilliant. I was invested in the dystopian Seattle, I was motivated to help my protagonist (Randall Wayne) find his family. But play past the first act and it regrettably develops into the most infuriating excuse for a platformer.

*Spoilers ahead*

You meet this man called Rat". You're cornered by a horde of zombies during a cutscene and the Rat drags you into a sewer saving your life. Nice guy? NO! He decides to strip you of all your weapons and then put you through the most mundane obstacle course  ever created! He's some crazed man that sensed the outbreak happening and built and under ground killing chamber. After a labored 30 minutes you "prove" yourself worthy and are allowed to leave... which of course means doing more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t puzzles to get to the ground!

The Rats sons missing above ground and you agree to go find him. Except some revolutionist military is chasing him.. then you and it never really makes any sense! At this point the game had lost all off the tension and atmosphere it had crafted at the beginning.

Once you're forced to move through the environments at speed (because of helicopters gunning you down from this stupid "military") the the controls become as slow as a zombie with no limbs trying to climb a hill
date: they single handedly crush the experience from the middle to the end of the game. I had to repeated a scripted section where you run through a house that's collapsing over 30 times because it controlled that appallingly. Sometimes I would roll
recommended:
sometimes I would not... sometimes I'd jump sometimes I'd get stuck on a wall and worst of all when I did get through a few times I'd die by invisible falling objects.  THAT'S NOT ALRIGHT!

I grew to hate the Randall Wayne. In cutscenes he looked like a rip off of solid snake.  Randall's over the top action "I'm a scary hardened survive man" voice was irritating and the things he'd say when walking through the environments where so BORING and STUPID that they made me laugh..not empathise!

They try dream sequences to attempt to evoke some sort of emotional connection but at the very end when you find out you'd killed your family..  aww haww... yup
hoursPlayed:
you killed the one's you'd be searching for the entire time and just "repressed" the memory and just decide after giving a huge speech about choices and fighting to another character you willing let zombies kill you (And its not like you saved the other girls life and sacrificed yourself.. Randall had plenty of time to get through the hole too)

I ain't never said ♥♥♥♥ YOU and ♥♥♥♥ THIS GAME so quickly in my entire life. I have rinsed my hands of it.

The only positive I can think of is the cutscenes are badass! Drawn like comic books I loved them

reviewText:
I've recently gotten into atmospheric platformers, and this game fills that hunger pretty well.

If you like atmospheric platformers, the zombie theme, and dark, gritty settings, then you will like Deadlight.

The aesthetics are great - the detail in the environment is very well-done. The screenshots do not do the game justice, and if you are able to play on medium to max settings, you will be greeted by a beautiful, dark world resulting from a zombie apocalypse. The sound and music is also very good, and adds to the seemingly hopeless aura projected by the story. The cutscenes are nice, however, if you have problems with the sound playing, make sure to check out the steam guide detailing how to fix this - you don't want to miss out on the writing.

The controls are pretty straighforward, and you are reminded of the controls whenever a new mechanic is introduced (or if you appear to be stucked). The tutorial (control) popups can be a bit noisy/intrusive, as they will appear in the middle of the screen and will show both the xbox controller and keyboard controls. The learning curve is minimal to moderate - the puzzles are not very challenging, and the game seems to be more of a storytelling narrative. You can choose to fight the zombies - referred to as shadows" - but most of the time it is more efficient to dodge them with some light parkour tricks (like jumping over vehicles or leaping across large gaps. The game provides checkpoints pretty regularly.

Overall
date: the gameplay and feel of the game is quite fluid - strengthening the atmospheric element as you continue to experience the story. For the achievement hunters
recommended: there are a number of "secrets" and collectibles
hoursPlayed: however
voteText: most of them are easy to find if you just explore the entirety of the levels (which usually consists of jumping across to a ledge you don't need to use). The feedback in the game is very helpful
helpfulPercent: always showing you when there is an object you can interact with.\n\nWhen using melee attacks
votesHelpful: your stamina bar will deplete - when you have low stamina
votesTotal: the screen will have a beating
votesFunny: tunnel vision effect
commentsCount: which I found to be a very nice touch. Headshots with the revolver are also cool to see. You can also taunt enemies to draw them toward you (so you can jump over them
column16: or use traps like dropping a car).\n\nPersonally
column17: one of the coolest
column18: most rewarding things to do in this game is to progress through an area quickly
column19: continuously leaping and wall jumping until you get to the next checkpoint. The smoothness and fluidity of the gameplay makes these speedruns look amazing. You might
column20: however
column21: also miss collectibles if you proceed too quickly.\n\nIf you are into the zombie theme and enjoy atmospheric puzzlers with a nice story

reviewText:
This is not a good game.  Far too many aspects are frustrating or badly designed for it to be worth any of your time or money.  If you need further persuasion than that - read on:

I bought and played this game after watching the trailer - and for what it shows it's accurate enough.  Parts of the game do look stylishly good and there are some free-running sections which work well and are even exhilerating.  But in almost every other aspect the game falls flat - and is on the whole entirely frustrating.

The story is abysmal - punctuated by truly horrible voice acting that will make you cringe and which is, for the most part, unskippable.  Additionally you are likely, even certain, to be forced to relisten to this terrible dialogue due to the checkpoint system and the game's mechanic of progression through death (or just plain old bugs).  On many occasions there will be no way to know that an upcoming location is deadly until you step into it - and you will have to repeat lengthy sections through no fault of your own.  This will get very old very quickly.  Especially in locations where the finicky and unreliable fence-climbing controls will lead to your demise right at the end of a section that you're now replaying for the fifth time.

There is no aspect of inventory / ammunition management or conservation as you will be given all the ammunition you need directly before you need it.  Find a box of shotgun shells? Zombie hoard dead ahead. Two bullets? Lonely zombie coming up.  Any ammunition you bother to save will periodically and suddently be taken from you by plot developments".

The only redeeming feature is that it ends very quickly and suddently.

Don't buy this game."

reviewText:
Yeah, everybody says it, the controls are somehow clunky and make the gameplay sometimes frustrating. But it's a 2D platformer, and except for Trine, all the ones I played are pretty much the same in terms of clunkiness and frustration. That doesn't make Deadlight any less nicer and it shouldn't make it so... underrated.

It comes with immersive, atmospheric visuals that make smart use of hues and nuances to make the game look really cool. I love the way it looks, though it's only a 2D platformer.

The story is also quite interesting and the voice acting is pretty nice. Deadlight also comes with Steam achievements and trading cards. Overall, I don't regret getting it at all, and I'm really sorry to see so many negative reviews about it just because people are used with too easy games nowadays.

reviewText:
It's pretty fun. An original take on the cliche 2D platformer genre, which has you avoiding zombies in unique ways, rather than blowing out every single infected's head. Granted, you do get a shotgun, revolver, and even a slingshot, but you'll spend more time hanging on powerlines, jumping from building to building, or on cars to avoid using those weapons.

Story is told primarily through the diary of the main character, Randal Wayne, and the environment. There are some very cool Walking Dead-esque style comic narration cutscenes, but they usually offer minimal dialogue to transition to different parts of the plot.

All in all, it's a solid little game, though to be completely honest, it's very short. I personally beat it in ~3 hours according to Steam. If you can find it for cheap during a holiday sale, I definitely recommend pulling the trigger.

reviewText:
The game is truly outrageous and epic! If you love some 2D graphic similar to Shank 2 or Bleed (Other 2D great games), this is really fit you then! The story take place around 1980s, and there are a huge zombies apocalypse. The main character are Randall Wayne, searching through the town for his lovely wife and daughter. It takes some strategy through many obstacles and free-running pass through lot of zombies. At the beginning, you start with your bare hands, later on, collect weapons and start to fight through your day! I would rate this 9/10, here are why:

Pros:
- Truly amazing graphic in 2D ( Made by Unreal Engine)
- Satisfying gameplay and story plot twist (Spoiler Alert!)
- Fanstatic free-style-running (parkour)
- Amazing voice actor and magnificent art
- Great sounds
- Have trading cards and steam cloud

Cons:
- Some places are really glitches and/or bugs ( trust me, you WILL find it)
- If you play 4+ hours, you should've been done the campaign (Short game)
- Don't have multiplayer or co-op ( Would've been cool)
- Somewhat realistic, combat is inconsistent

Here is my opinion for this game:) Hope to help someone out before buying this game! Got it in sale! Worth the money!

reviewText:
A zombie genre take on a side-scrolling classic like Another World, Flashback and Heart of Darkness.

The plot is fairly predictable, filled with clichés and the scripting is pretty poor in quite a few places, but the game itself is worthwhile.

Set in and around Seattle in 1986, there's a lot of interesting scenery and locations. A lot of the environmental puzzles are really well designed and there's a feeling of exploring a grimly beautiful diorama.

A few of the chapters had really fun gameplay elements, but felt like they were completely un-needed for the story. The game has a 'twist', and quite a modest attempt at putting a lot of thought behind it all, especially in the form of diary pages, which you find as you explore. However, this level of the story requires quite a lot of patience reading through the pages you find.

The game has a well implemented checkpoint feature, respawning you generally just a few moments before you made your fatal error. Each scene is a puzzle and the game generally doesn't punish you for making a mistake. I did encounter a couple of moments where I was set back about a minutes worth of gameplay, which felt frustrating but only by comparison to how good the system usually was.

Overall, good clichéd fun and an interesting merge of gameplay and genre.

reviewText:
Deadlight is an atmospheric and story-driven 2.5D zombie survival platformer that doesn't focus on the typical run-and-gun mechanics of most of the other zombie games but instead puts the spotlight on the story and the survival aspects of a zombie apocalypse.

The game is powered by the Unreal Engine, so visually the game looks pretty great for a 2.5D sidescroller. Both the visual fidelity and the detailed and lovingly crafted levels build up a nightmarish atmosphere and underlines the horror of a zombie-infested city.

I won't talk much about the story. While it isn't exactly innovative, it's the way the story is told that keeps you going on. Secrets you find across the levels give you an even deeper insight of what happened and why. Oh, and the ending comes with a pretty surprising twist...

As mentioned before, the game focuses on the survival aspect, so while you do find guns in the game, you rather rarely find ammo for them and mostly end up using the guns to shoot padlocks or other 'puzzle' elements.

Gameplay-wise, Deadlight doesn't exactly re-invent the wheel and comes with the typical platforming and combat controls. There are no special moves, whacky weapons or the likes, so it's all pretty much basic platformer-101.

Since this is a platformer, there is a lot of, uh, platforming going on. Most of the time not really challenging, you come across a couple parts where things can get quite frustrating, e.g. where you have to escape a collapsing building and stuff like that. Luckily enough, the checkpoints are placed pretty well, so you rarely end up having to re-play a large chunk of the level in order to get back to where you died, but still, I feel like a bit more fine-tuning wouldn't have hurt the platforming aspect of the game.

According to the ingame stats, it took me 06h46m to beat the game. That involved 100%-ing the game (finding all secrets and bonuses), quite a bit of trial-and-error and a whole lot of dying. Personally, I think that's pretty much the right length for a game like this but it surely can be beaten in 5 hours or less if you don't care about finding the secrets and don't die as often as I did... :D

So, Deadlight won't exactly win any innovation awards, but it certainly approaches the zombie genre from a slightly different direction than the typical zombie-slaugher games, which works out really well. Together with the solid platforming mechanics and the gripping story-telling, Tequila Works managed to release a detailed and pretty impressive debut game, so one can hope they keep up the quality for a possible sequel.

Definitely worth checking out!

reviewText:
I forgot how I got my hands on this game, to be honest. I found it in my library one day and after watching the trailer I decided to give it a try. It somehow reminded me of Mark Of The Ninja, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. and Left4Dead all together and this couldn't be a bad thing.

This being said, it's not much to say about the game.

The game looks great and has an awesome artistic direction as well as a nice story (wouldn't call it good but it's enjoyable. The soundtrack is very good and fits perfectly with the somber atmosphere of this game.

Naturally, being a platformer,  there are a lot of simple puzzles to solve. In fact, the second chapter (the game is split into 3 chapters) of the game is full of them and it feels like it was especially designed to have as many puzzles as possible.

Unfortunately, the game has it's issues.

The most annoying thing is the clunky controls that can make the game frustrating since it has many trial-and-error moments

Button response is slow and extremely unresponsive. Same goes for the aiming system.
Trying to jump of a fence can make you jump back to the side you're coming from, in the middle of the zombies.
Trying to make a sprint right after jumping down from a fence or windows usually doesn't work and you have to try holding the sprint key a few times.
Jumping while you are sliding down on a wall or floor doesn't work as it should or takes too long to respond, making you miss the jump window and retry again and again. Sometimes, jumping when running won't work so you'll find yourself stumbling upon boxed all the time. And since getting up is slow, you'll most likely end up being eaten by shadows.

It also has some bugs in the last chapter of the game. Reaching the top of the stairs that end up with a shaft causes the shaft to close before you get out, pushing you out of the map. Also, this happens when you try to get inside a building or room through a window. The window opens before you can get on the other side and you get stuck there so you need to restart the checkpoint.

The last chapter unfortunately is full of bugs and the controls feel worse here. Escaping the military base is a nightmare. I encountered all those bugs there. Also, the interact button as well as using the ax to break things are extremely unresponsive here.

Of course, these problems won't occur when you use a controller showing that this game was designed with a controller in mind, something you can see in the videos in the extras menu, after you finish the game.

However, leaving all these problems aside and the fact that the game is very short (you can finish it in less than 2 hours on your second playthrough), the game is enjoyable and fun to play and definitely worth a few bucks.

7/10

reviewText:
Deadlight, another game set in a post-apocalyptic world full of zombies? Yes, but how much fun was to play it!!

This is a platformer where you play as Randall, a survivor who's trying to reach Seattle in order to find his wife and daughter, lost after the disaster. On his road through run-down and abandoned suburbs, he will find hate, hope and madness, all seasoned with a good amount of undead.

Gameplay is based on survivor skills and environmental puzzle solving, but ferocious combat is not missing and Randall will be able to use an axe, a pistol and a shotgun (do I need to list also the slingshot?). Not that much you will say, and I would agree, except that the game is not very long to finish (4-5 hours), so I think the amount of differentiation between weapons, amount of levels and types of enemies is just right.

It is clear that originally Deadlight was intended as a low budget indie title, and it is a shame that the developer had no more resources in order to extend and deepen Randall's personal story, maybe with more flashbacks from his past, or even only with more levels, enemies and weapons. 2.5 graphics are just perfect to represent this diseased world full of oppressive atmospheres, and the main musial theme is really awesome, so moody!!

Do not let the abused zombie theme fool you, Deadlight is a nice game if you like the genre, it offers the right amount of contents and fun for its price. Now I just need to understand if I want to deal with the just unlocked Nightmare mode :)

reviewText:
With so many zombie themed games, most of them essentially copying each other, Dead Light brings a new perspective for a zombie outbreak, with a 2D scenario, with limited movement and focusing on strategy and resource managing.

Every movement must be previously planned, as some actions require stamina, which is limited, and ammo is very scarce and must be used wisely. DL is different because it makes you think to solve all the puzzles, not just shooting around to progress through levels.

It's indeed a great piece of work, with photorealistic graphics, good controls, good plot, and good mechanics.

If you get the chance, buy it and try a different approach for a zombie game.

reviewText: Deadlight reintroduces us to a vintage and tragic world. Vintage as based on old-school Side-scrolling and Tragic as based on the end of the human race. This near 3D side scrolling ZOMBIE infested nightmare will bring you to the edge of your wits as you play as an unlikely common Survivalist named Randall Wayne. You set out to find your missing family and along the way will meet various and random Survivors both friend and foe. In the ruined city you’ll need to run along from platform to platform avoiding or killing the walking dead better known as Shadows. These shadows and not your garden variety group of ZOMBIES. They will not infect you, they will not taunt you; they will merely KILL you. This adventure offers a side order of hunting for hidden clues and objects and the opportunity to increase health and stamina. Each scene is re-playable so you can go back and search for missing items. Your weapons are limited and unique for the situation. This has been a lot of fun to play and left me wanting more.

reviewText:
Great game.  Quite short but I didn't mind much.  I love the atmosphere and the overall concept.  Almost everything is perfect.
What's not perfect is the cutscenes sometimes don't play sound, which I solved by watching them on YouTube but there's some other update fix and not everyone's computer has this problem apparently; the controls are slightly imperfect (chiefly when turning round and performing another action, or hoping to jump straight up but not being absolutely motionless before trying; no-thing terrible but occasionally annoying); and some odd bugs, like things triggering in a strange way if you backtrack (especially checkpoints; I had to reload from the beginning of an area because of this, though I believe there was another fix that I didn't feel like finding as I was only a few minutes in), and some of the default UDK texture appearing on a couple of objects.

But overall, I found the game quite immersive and was glad to play a well executed platformer for the first time in a long time.  The music is brilliant.  The design is ingenious.  The analogue aiming was very interesting and I liked it.

A lot of people don't like the sewer section.  I admit the first portion of the game is probably the best but the sewer is just a platformer throwback and it's done fairly well.  It's a lot like Abe's Oddysee (I haven't played the remake so I'm talking about the PS1 game).

I didn't buy it at full price but I never buy any thing unless it's almost free, so...maybe that helped.  It is short after all.

reviewText:
As Randall Wayne you're a survivor in a world decimated by Shadows (basically zombies), barely surviving with a small group of people in Seattle. You're suddendly separated and embark on a journey to find what happened to them and with hope to also find your wife and daughter amidst the chaos.
Deadlight is an ok platformer with a simple yet intriguing storyline and great atmosphere: it's a shame that it tries, sometimes succeeding, to ruin your fun with awkward controls and some frustrating sections.

PROS:

-good graphics and art style showing a destroyed Seattle, the areas you'll explore and the background scenery are truly bleak and beautiful in their own way

-good soundtrack

-the voice acting is pretty good especially on the main character

-Randall Wayne is a well-written main character, a man stopping at nothing to survive while also being haunted by its past

-the zombies are actually menacing and very dangerous (in part, sadly, due to the awkward controls)

-decent plot with a good ending section: there's also an alternative ending- unlocked by beating the atrocious Nightmare mode- that gives you a different take on the events of the game, I recommend you look it up on Youtube once you've finished the game

CONS:

-controls are sometimes unresponsive or extremely finicky, grappling a ledge or a ladder won't work properly unless you're positioned exactly right next to it, sometimes it'll take a split second too long to actually start jumping or running- due to delay in controls- and this'd easily spell your doom

-combat is so-so as firearms work well enough but melee combat is overly random: sometimes you'll decapitate or trip a zombie with a single hit while other fights see you bashing their heads repeatedly with little to no effect before getting overwhelmed and eaten

-some levels delve into trial and error affairs requiring you to memorize the whole sequence while also hoping the controls won't let you down: this isn't fun and can get frustrating

-Nightmare mode, where the game saves only at the beginning of each Act, is an asinine proposition considering you can often die due to unresponsive controls

-some assorted bugs due to it being a lazy port such as framerate drops, the game hanging and sometimes crashing while trying to access the start menu etc...some of those can be solved through workarounds posted on the forums but it's unacceptable nonetheless

-pretty short and linear, no real replay value

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=515362638

Deadlight does as many things right as it does wrong...the unresponsive and sometimes buggy controls, paired with some overly difficult sections, can really get in the way of your fun: this gets very clear during the second half of the game, with a few acts sporting truly annoying scenes where a single mistake or bug in the controls will see you die. Thankfully there's always a checkpoint near so you won't be losing much progress and it's not as bad as some reviews make it out to be, even though I'm not really into the genre I managed to get through said sections in a few tries.

While dodgy controls in a platformer are an unforgivable sin the game does manage to pull itself through thanks to a story that, while surely full of survival/ zombie cliches, is quite engaging and features a few twists to keep you interested. There's also a great atmosphere to be found in the game's bleak graphics, Seattle is truly a zombie infested ruin with abandoned vehicles, crumbling walls and corpses everywhere. Last but not least Randall was an enjoyable character to control with a strong voice acting and an interesting take on things through both its thoughts and diary pages.

Deadlight is a decent game overall if you can be patient with its obvious shortcomings and I feel it's worth a playthrough for any zombie fan: do not buy at full price though since it's simply not worth that much, wait for the big sales where it's under the 2$ mark.

reviewText:
I must admit that I have an unnatural attraction to play zombie apocalypse games, so I was quite eager to see what Deadlight had to offer.

At this point in time, I am quite sure that most people reading this review are familiar with the concept of zombie apocalypse. If not - here is the concept in broad strokes: Due to some mysterious reason (either virus outbreak, genetic mutations or just something strange in the water), the recently deceased start rising back as flesh eating zombies (which from now on will be referred as shadows, to be consistent with the game nomenclature), killing and infecting everyone they scratch or bite. Only a selected few manage to escape the outbreak, and this is  where  the struggle for survival begins - not only from the shadows, that are just looking for an healthy snack - but also from ruthless groups of survivors that prey from the weak.

So, it is in this setting that we find our character - Randall Wayne -  traveling alongside a small group of survivors in hopes of finding a reported Safe Point" in Seattle. We meet the group when a member just got bitten (as invariably happens) and head shot by Randall for the greater good . It is common knowledge that gunfire will attract shadows to you as fire attracts moths

reviewText:
There is an oversaturation in the zombie genre these days, especially in the gaming market.
Sadly 90% of them suck.The good thing is that Deadlight is not in that 90%.

It's not the best zombie game out there, the story/voice over are pretty average.
But what you get is an interesting platformer with some great art and level design.
The Campaign can last you about 7 hrs which is a decent length for a platformer.

7/10 Verdict: If you need to play then Mr. Steam sale will be your friend.

reviewText:
Deadlight is a beautiful game, but the graphics just aren't enough to salvage it.

The core gameplay is fun enough, but the controls make it more frustrating than it needs to be.

It's challenge level is fairly accessible, but the last chapter is a straight-up rage game, brutally difficult only because of the surprises it throws at you the first time through.

The backgrounds are incredibly detailed, but they'll have you wondering why your character doesn't just take the clearly visible stairs instead of forcing himself through jumping puzzles.

The main character is reasonably well voice acted, but he's surrounded by a cast reading a laughable script in bad American accents.

The story is nothing new, with an ending you'll see coming from the first cutscene.  Although, if you play through the game on Nightmare mode, I guarantee you you'll be surprised -- the secret ending may make no sense at all, but at least it is unexpected.

Two final notes: there's no in-game reward for gathering all the collectibles, so it is safe to skip doing that, and this game has absolutely no Metroidvania aspects at all -- it is a perfectly linear platformer from start to finish.

All in all I can't recommend Deadlight but if it is on sale for cheap it might be worth it for a few hours of themed jumping puzzles.

reviewText:
After playing for a few hours I can say I do enjoy the game and beleive its worth the $5 I paid durring the Steam Summer Sale 2013.

I like the 2D side scroller old school type gaming with depth of field and the realisitic graphocs really do bring these types of games to life.

The game plays awesome and I like the little story plot. The cut scenes however are still images and I don't like that, they should have been cgi movie quality scenes and not basic images.

Don't expect to have hours and hours of fun on this but do expect to have a few hours fun and enjoyment.

Personaly I wouldn't pay more then $5 for this game as the hours worth of play and the cutscenes really do bring hurt the overall experience for a game listed at $15.

reviewText:
Wow! A side-scroller that uses Unreal Engine 3! No wonder the game looks beautiful. Developed by the Spanish Tequila Works, Deadlight is a survival horror platformer game taking place in the '80s during a zombie outbreak. I guess there were two reasons for picking mentioned era: best platformers we refer to as classics were made in those days and as there were no internet and mobile phones at that time the game can really grasp the atmosphere of isolation during the incident.

The game was criticised for its controls - I agree as there are stages where I needed to try and try again after dying many times as I was not able to carefully plan a jump. Also, while the game looks stunning you do not really have a lot of time to look around as the infected are approaching and quick reaction is necessary.

Overall, this is a very good game. Somewhat short and can be maddeningly difficult, Deadlight proves there can be a need for sidescrollers out there and these can be made by utilising modern day's technology.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game! I played this game with a controller since it's a sidescrolling platform game. It might sound very limited that this game is viewed from the side, but the sound and atmosphere enhances the gaming experience, so you're not losing experience because of it.

You're playing Randall Wayne - a survivor of a zombie apocalypse. Trying to get his way through to Seattle, Randall is forced to be very physical with the world by climbing, jumping, shooting and slashing in order to get to  safety. He will come face to face with people who are also trying to survive this mad world and some of these people are not exactly friendly.

The only negative aspect of this game is that it's a bit too short. I managed to finish it in 6 hours and I was not rushing it, I like to explore and check out every nooks and crannies. Regardless I still enjoyed the game not to mention the goodies you'll find like retro games scattered all over the map that you can play - Play games in game!

Peace.

reviewText:
pros: great aesthetics, fitting soundtrack, solid platforming mechanics, collectables, fair checkpoints for the most part

cons: ive experienced a few unstable crashes, clunky combat animations, lag spikes when loading new areas/scripted events, some sections had poor level designs especially the last few levels

reviewText: I'm a sucker for pretty 2D platformers. This one has a rather good-looking dark 2.5D urban zombie-apocalypse setting. It's a puzzle platformer with a little bit of combat and gritty graphic-novel style cutscenes. There were some frustrating parts due to platforms blending in with the background or your character responding slowly to controls during chase scenes, and there are annoying obstacles and traps that are only obstacles in the 2D plane, but overall I really enjoyed it, if mostly for the great setting, environments, and aesthetic style.

If you neglect that part, and some bugs, the game is a rather enjoyable 2.5D game, by some defined as short. Seeing as I played this long ago and I am now continuing, so I cannot confirm it. While the game idea itself is kinda nice (Limbo meets zombie survival), both the story and the controls leave you hoping for more. The story is exceptionally weak to the point of making me want to punch my wall bloody. Also for a game that relies quite a lot on exact movement, the controls are uncharasteristically poor. Your character rarely moves as you would like and in a game like this, it causes lots of problems. The handheld game collectables were a nice touch, though.

At least the game was short.

reviewText:
Let me start with this: what a wonderful gem of a game.
A great side scroller with excellent backgrounds and a fantastic story.

It was good to see an alternate timeline to where the zombie apocalypse started. It isn't a long game, but what it there is powerful and gripping, and you can't pull yourself away until you finish it.
I just wanted to explore the beautiful levels and leave no stone unturned because there are collectables that fit into the story quite nicely.

If you want something that isn't the same old zombie cliche then this is a good game.
It has zombies by all means, but it is mostly about the way people interact in this game. And by interect I mean looking out for themselves and shooting you given the chance.

10/10 would learn how to swim before the zombie apocalypse.

reviewText: The storyline and voice acting are pretty good, and the concept of gameplay is sound. However, the tremendously unresponsive controls just end up being too frustating deal with. Things like, you can't hit zombies while they're standing up,  (you have to wait for them to finish their animation), taking a long time to swing backwards, etc.
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Graphics are good. Voice acting is also quite good. As for the story, although there is nothing new (typical post-apocalyptic scenario: zombies trying to kill you, other people trying to kill you, people trying to use you, and you're trying to find your friends/family), it is fine, too.

But the controls are unbearable. This game doesn't seem to be designed for PC. Controls feel clumsy, the character will not move as you wish, you'll fail to interact with environment/enemies as you desire, and sometimes the character will not do what he supposed to do because of bad controls (I'm referring to the collapsing building but there are other parts, too).

You'll fail and die not because of the difficulty (this game is not hard for sure) but because of the controls, and this is annoying

As I said at the beginning, this game has good aspects. Nevertheless, for this kind of game, one of important things is the quality of controls, and the game fails at this point.

I'm sorry but I cannot recommend this game.
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Deadlight is an amazing little game that could've used a little more polish. Let me explain: the game plays like a platformer. It's all 2.5D by the way, so everything is in 3D, but the gameplay itself is restricted to a 2D plane.

Now, the graphics are nothing short of amazing. It's some of the best art I've ever seen. It's bloody brilliant.

The voice acting is alright. Some of the characters could've used a little more emotion at times. It's a place filled with zombies, damn it, so act like it !

The story will keep you interested until the end, which most of us will reach in 3-5 hours, depending on if you're collecting and searching everything.

So, so far it's all good. But near the end you'll be dying an awful lot. And not the good, challenging-kind of dying, but the occasionally-unresponsive-controls-kind of dying. There's one scene I must have done literally about 20 times. It. Was/Is. Infuriating.

But despite this flaw I would still highly recommend it to all zombie fans out there.

[Rating: 82/100]

reviewText:
Seattle simulator exploring the case where tech gigants decided not to settle down in Washington.

Now seriously, It was okay-ish.

Starts really good then starts spinning down towards boring end. Gets caught up in bad puzzles where you must use derivatives of moves you learned earlier - catch is, they seem pretty impossible physically. As you progress throught the game you end up repeating numerous times puzzle sequences that require a timely use of specific actions/combinations of moves - if you fail, instakill and repeat.
Story is somewhat average - 1/3 of the game is a boring episode disconnected from main plot that someone pushed inside the game storyline and glued the ends together to make it fit with entire story arc.
Good asthetics and looks - game has a nice sinking theme of apocalpyse.

reviewText:
Gritty/10

Next time, hire an actual writer, eh guys?

Other than that, the movement is not fluid enough for the chase/timed sequences, but the overall parkourness of it is immensely satisfying. Coupled with the beautiful backdrops, it provides a sense of space unlike any other. Combat is clunky and the game does a good job of steering you away from it.

It is a post-apoc walking sim, basically. And for that, I give it a thumbs up.

reviewText: When I first started Deadlight, I was instantly captivated by the atmosphere it created. Then it introduced clunky combat, and I thought, oh well, it's a zombie game, so I should feel weak and uncoordinated. I kept playing, and realized, no wait, this game is just sadistic. Jumping puzzles that require you to stand in exactly the right place, running sequences that require you to guess where the developer put traps, nonsensical puzzles- if you like tight, well-thought-out platforming, you've come to the right place.\nThrow in a second-thought plot and voice acting that sounds like it came from a high school play, and you've got Deadlight.

reviewText:
Trochę oklepana fabuła, plus nieskończone wątki prowadzące do nikąd, ale fajny klimat przez większość gry.

Nierównomierny poziom trudności (są momenty, które wymagają wręcz perfekcji, żeby było gorzej, przy każdej próbie słyszymy ten sam komentarz głównego bohatera, co doprowadza do jeszcze większej irytacji).

Fajnie wygląda - bardzo ładne tła zniszczonego przez apokalipsę zombi Seattle. Ambient w tle dodaje klimaciku.

Gierka trochę przypomina mi Limbo połączone lekko z The Last of Us.

Zabawy starczy na jakieś 3h, jak na tego typu grę jest to wystarczająco długo.

6/10 :)

reviewText:
As an Atmospheric/Survival Horror/Zombie Apocalypse game fan I have mixed to positive feeling about this game.
would give this game 7.5/10.

The game itself is an intersting and enjoyable experience for me.
it is not heavily combat-based, and has extrondinary art style and unique game design.
the story is shallow, but the ending managed to touch me.

The game controls are not very keybord-friendly. It woud be a pain to use it in several levels.
The death run level? Good luck using the keyboard with default keys. Try switching between the LShift and LCtrl keys and pressing them with your pinkie. I borke a nail doing just that.
I would recommend using a controller instead.

Not gonna spoil anything heavily related to the story so read on.

Here's the list of the noticable things I did in the game.
·tripped over a chair
·turned down a rat meat dinner offer
·did some kick-♥♥♥ parkour to get IDs of random dead guys
·tripped over a chair again
·Witnessed a sence from attack on titans" in one of my dreams
·Suffered the consequences of not being able to swim

ps. Aslo. Hotdogs are censored in this game. It is truly a living hell on Earth."

Glad I paid 1€ for the game.

Later on I was really annoyed by this game. The playthrough felt like work.

Graphics are really nice, especially when you got the city in the background, which makes a great atmosphere. The game runs good also.
The Controls felt good, altho sometimes I had problems with the timing. I was playing it with a Xbox 360 Controller.

And thats where the game deserves criticism. It's SO linear. No surprise and not even bad for me in general, but it's so extreme, there are hardly any alteranate routes to use, and if you're not exactly performing how the game wants you to, you simply die. Over and over. You need to stand at the exact point, shoot at the exact time e.g.

I like hard games but this made me mad. Doing the same Sequence 10 times and experiencing glitches (which make you die..) really kills the fun.

The dialogues are bad, the story has major flaws in it's solution and the whole game doesn't make you care about the characters or the world in general.
It feels like the engine, gameplay etc. has a big potential, but the boring story and foreseeable end really made me dislike the game.

The good gameplay and nice graphics can't make up for that.

When finished, 'Nightmare' mode got unlocked. Already felt like having a nightmare in first place tho.
Oh and it took me roughly 3 hours to play through the game.

reviewText:
It's Prince of Persia-lite, with zombies added to keep it fresh.  You know, zombies?  Those things that have been failing to keep anything fresh since The Walking Dead came out and caused every last entertainment medium to become saturated with zombies?  Yeah, those.  Hope you still love 'em, cause they haven't changed.

Anyway, the visuals are pretty good, the voice acting would have made the plunge into parody if it were any worse, the plot weaves makes frequent dips into nonsense, and the ending is insultingly bad.

At the time of review, this game is selling for about a buck and a quarter.  If the ending hadn't made me want to dropkick my monitor, I might be able to recomment trying it for that price.

Go play Limbo instead.

reviewText: The game was pretty fun but fairly short. There were a couple of places that were incredibly frustrating because there was no room for error, yet the controls are imprecise. The controls are completely fine for the more open, less pressured areas, but when having to run through a collapsing building and make perfect jumps in time to avoid being crushed, the small flaws rear their head to make you miserable. However, I still enjoyed the game overall. The atmosphere is great, and the puzzles are entertaining. Not worth the full $15 in my opinion (I completed the game in slightly more than 3 hours, which means I could have just gone to see a movie and spent less money for about the same amount of entertainment, and we all know how much movies cost these days), but well worth picking up on the cheap during a Steam sale.

reviewText:
The game has its ups and downs.

The good: Great story telling, convincing narrative, and seamless integration make the experience easy to immerse yourself in.

The bad: Various points in the game introduce instant-kill mechanics that you need to learn through trial and error, and with so much dying and reloading to figure it out, the immerison is lost.

Overall however, this is some high quality work. Nightmare mode is unpolished and unimaginative, and for the reasons mentioned above relating to unforgiving instant kills, I would not attempt it myself.

reviewText: Excellent game, story driven with an enthralling narrative and innovative gameplay. Be warned though, some puzzles are repetitve and sometimes the controls will leave you swearing. If you play with a gamepad you will fare much better than with keyboard & mouse. The repetitiveness can dole down the excellent atmosphere the game generates (a scary scene you play for the 5th time is a little less scary) but the same goes for any platformer. I love games with narrators - I'm looking at you Bastion - and this one does not disappoint. I was hooked after my first minute of play and did not really stop before I had finished it. reviewText:
Deadlight is a survival horror side scroller. Odd combo you might think, but much like games like Trine it takes it's 2D plane and packs in an AMAZING amount of detail all over that really set the scene of post apocalyptic Seattle. You play Randall, a man who has survived becoming a Shadow" and is trying to find his family and reach a safe haven.

This is a first impressions review:

To start off like I said the detail is amazing
date: growing up in the Pacific Northwest seeing the detail they put into the areas really made me happy and gave a me a nearly home feeling (despite the fact it was destroyed). The game has a nice flow to it and controls pretty smoothly. The character so far is believable and has a reasonable enough agenda. And he looks exactly like a rough guy from Seattle would.\n\nThe fact that you rather avoid zombies than kill them due to stamina and lack of ammo really brings in the survival horror feel for me
recommended: and the planning in obstacles really polishes the side scrolling bit. My pet peeves arise from two things however
hoursPlayed: one some of the obstacles are a bit tedious
voteText: seeing as they might require a still jump but naturally it's hard to place yourself under it and you end up jumping all over and wasting time. The second is a stricly mouse and keyboard issue
helpfulPercent: the aiming of the gun being just a bit too stiff to really gun down a zombie about to bite me.\n\nOverall this game is definitely worth getting from what I've seen in just my first hour of playing."

reviewText: Deadlight's biggest appeal is its great visual style and atmosphere. Everything looks excellent and there's a good amount of depth to each location to help break up the 2D side-scroller feel. You play a character named Randall, who's been separated from his friends and family and is looking for them. The storyline is pretty throw-away. Around the 2/3 mark the game really starts to lose steam and resorts to some pretty cheap instant death traps and timed segments that rely on precision jumping skills. Unfortunately, the game's controls aren't quite as precise as they need to be to accomplish these sections without dying repeatedly due to your character being unresponsive to your inputs. More than a few times Randall will just stay attached to a wall or fence, refusing to jump, despite the jump button being pressed repeatedly. This gets really frustrating really fast. It's a pretty short game too, only taking a few hours to complete. I'd recommend picking it up if you can get it for $5 or less. Overall, I'd give it a 6/10.

reviewText:
Deadlight is a very atmospheric experience: its plot serves to tell a simple, yet powerful tale; its visuals are an effective mix of 3D graphics and a 2D sidescroller perspective; the game plays with its colour palette and lighting; the gameplay is a mix of platforming and survival horror elements – combat really is the last resort here. The puzzles aren't very complex or challenging, but they are thought-provoking enough to keep the experience engaging.

Many of Deadlight's greatest features are due to the appropriately gauged ambition of its designers. The development team knew that they could not make everything work with a low budget and so few hands on the project. For that reason they stuck only with things that worked for the game. What you're left with is a short, sweet, highly atmospheric and engrossing indie platformer.

The setting is very unoriginal and the controls sometimes seem a bit awkward when using a mouse and keyboard, but every aspect of the game reinforces its creepy atmosphere – and this is why Deadlight succeeds. Grab it in a sale though, because the 4 hours it takes to complete the game are not much for £10 – even with the unlockable extras that the game has to offer.

reviewText: A beautiful little platform/puzzler. A mix of Limbo, Left for Dead and the original Prince of Persia. Its a really well visualised world which really does have the feel of the post zombie apocalypse world and there's a wonderfu;l fluidity to it. Really a very good little indie game. Its not massively long but then it doesn't need to be. The plot's great and the little comic-strip cut scenes don't detract from the action. Only flaw is some slightly ropey collision detection". Zombies in the background are all of a sudden on top of you. All in all though and very enjoyable game. Score 9/10"
