reviewText:
Deadlight oozes a lot potential and promise during the first 60-90 minutes, but unfortunately it fails to live up to that potential the rest of the way. The game is divided into three acts: The first act plays like a high-quality survival-horror platformer with limited focus on combat. The atmosphere is terrific and this is by far the high point of the campaign. The second act, though, stumbles horribly into a platforming/puzzle-solving mess that's made annoying by the game's awful controls that just never feel right at all. The third act strives to get back to the style of the first act, and at times succeeds in doing so, but unfortunately it's just not able to recapture that early magic.

From a visual standpoint, Deadlight is simply stunning. It has a really great art style that will make you stop and admire the gloomy Pacific Northwest backdrop. The game also features some top-notch sound design. From a story standpoint, it's mostly a forgettable tale that's riddled with bad voicework.

Deadlight feels like a game that really could've been something special if the devs had stuck to the formula of the first act, tightened the controls, and made the puzzles more challenging than they were. Instead it's a game that begins to fall apart after the first 90 minutes before picking itself up during the final stretch and crossing the finish line with a limp. Decent yet disappointing.

reviewText:
Let me be up-front and say this:  THIS GAME'S CONTROLS ARE A NIGHTMARE.

Sometimes you'll press a button and he'll do the command facing the wrong direction.  Sometimes you'll tell your guy to switch weapons like FIVE TIMES IN A ROW AND AUUGHHHH I DIED AHHH.  Then as soon as you respawn he just switches weapons five times in a row.  Sometimes you'll press pause, and it takes a solid 2 minutes for the pause menu to come up.  Sometimes you'll aim your gun and pull the trigger thinking a zombie is about get splattered but it just does absolutely nothing instead.  The controls and general layout of this game are atrocious.

That being said, I still keep coming back to it.  Normally I would have long abandoned a game that felt this sloppy, but I really like it for some reason.  If you can pick this up on sale, and can put up with restarting the same checkpoint 800 times in a row because your guy" didn't quite do what you wanted
date: pick it up.  If you have to pay more than a few bucks for it

reviewText:
Deadlight is a good game with a quite unique atmosphere. The platformer elements with the background really creates a feeling where there's no fighting off zombies, only running away or finding a shelter.

And while the game itself is fun, there are some thing that could've been improved. Too many a times you can find yourself in a situation where you need to do exactly what the level designer had in mind or you're dead. Not standing exactly where needed, a bit glitchy jumping, or action sequences where it seems you did everything right, yet you're reverted back to a checkpoint - and then it turns out doing the same thing second time actually works.
It's not really bad enough to annoy, but it is sufficient to break the immersion.

Overall a fine, short game for one evening.

reviewText:
The most beautiful zombie game I have ever played and it was a side scroller. What Deadlight lacks in 3D in has in depth of perspective. This game was truly well made and had very few flaws, but it did have two in my eyes.

The backgrounds that were full of depth, movement and detail made you feel engrossed in a dying world. Yes this game is a side scrolling game but you will barely notice as the developers make the 2D palette look truly deep. The music and sound add completeness to a world that you both fear and admire. The game overall was straight forward and not overly difficult but yet it still wasn't a cake walk. I did feel at times when you failed a certain point and it made you redo an entire segment that required precise jumps and actions; was frustrating. I felt like at the times the overall story lacked some definition and forced you to read diary pages in order to fill in the blanks; I don't want to sit and read through pages of story.  The ending will be somewhat expected and not overly shocking, but you will enjoy it on some level. Overall the gameplay which consisted of tough jumps and some shooting was enjoyable yet not groundbreaking.

If you appreciate great artwork, zombies, great gameplay and decent audio then Deadlight is the game for you.

+ Amazing Artwork
+ Enjoyable Voice Acting
+ Fun gameplay
- Frustrating punishments for small mistakes
- Lacking story that forced out of game reading.

Score: 8 out of 10

reviewText:
Deadlight is one of the more memorable zombie games ive played and heres why:

The Story, The World, The Zombies
This is a 2.5D game and a nice one at that, the atmosphere is compelling and the journey you take is enjoyable to say the least. From the start your a little in over your head, the zombies are out in force and you have to run, run where? well to find your family obviously (seriously... every time.) But who cares the art style is beautiful, and the gameplay is fun.

Axes, Guns and Delusions
Bring you axe, bring your pistol, bring your shotgun and dont forget to pick up the pieces of your journal along the way, but dont ask me how all these pages got ahead of you, I honestly dont know but its a nice feature to flesh out the story and take a break from the Linear for a little light reading.

The Characters (Spoilers, Spoilers everywhere!)
Its hard to really describe any of the characters as you get about 5 second with them each before they suffer a horrible death. Right from the start we see ourself killing a zombie bitten friend and then were split off from the others in a hearbeat, when we finally catch up with a member of our crew he is within the last seconds of his life, and our final two members are kidnapped by the new law. From the three of us left, two die, ill give you two guesses. There is however one reclusive character we meet who is more fleshed out and actually very interesting The Rat" and he's build himself a junkyard fortress of Death underground
date:
thats just awesome right? it is.

Overall Rating: 7.5/10

Why I gave this Rating:
If I was to rate this game on atmosphere alone it would get 10/10 for being one of the more beautiful/atmospheric zombie games i've played (Beautiful being an odd choice of word for a zombie game but still.) As a whole the game followed a pretty generic storyline
recommended: and a short one at that
hoursPlayed: I completed the game in a single 2-3 hour sitting; this isnt all bad however for as short as it is its memorable and doesnt burn you out from endless levels. The fact that you learn very little about the personality or anything for that matter for the vast majority of characters introduced (including the new law
voteText: our evil enemy faction) also affected my rating. Overall I enjoyed this game and if what i've wrote is "your thing" you will to."

reviewText:
Deadlight is brilliant. Picked it up on the xbox when it came out and again on steam during the sale.
The game presents itself so well for such a simple design of side-scrolling. There is a lot of interaction with the environment and the backgrounds offer a lot of involvement with gameplay. Zombies lie waiting, feasting on a fallen survivor and when you make your move past the group, they will come into your plane and chase you down until you can trick them into falling into a crevasse. The attention to detail is highly impressive, too. When you wade through low, muddy waters, you will see your feet kicking up piles of mud. Everything about the game has some bit of detail to it.

If you're on the fence about Deadlight, I can highly recommend the game. It is worth more than a blank check, let a lone $3 on sale. Buy this game. You will not be disappointed. I would not be surprised if developer Tequila Works sees huge success in coming years from only Deadlight. Any fan of zombie games will have a blast with the game. Bravo, Tequila Works.

reviewText:
Deadlight is a good game with a quite unique atmosphere. The platformer elements with the background really creates a feeling where there's no fighting off zombies, only running away or finding a shelter.

And while the game itself is fun, there are some thing that could've been improved. Too many a times you can find yourself in a situation where you need to do exactly what the level designer had in mind or you're dead. Not standing exactly where needed, a bit glitchy jumping, or action sequences where it seems you did everything right, yet you're reverted back to a checkpoint - and then it turns out doing the same thing second time actually works.
It's not really bad enough to annoy, but it is sufficient to break the immersion.

Overall a fine, short game for one evening.

reviewText: When I first started Deadlight, I was instantly captivated by the atmosphere it created. Then it introduced clunky combat, and I thought, oh well, it's a zombie game, so I should feel weak and uncoordinated. I kept playing, and realized, no wait, this game is just sadistic. Jumping puzzles that require you to stand in exactly the right place, running sequences that require you to guess where the developer put traps, nonsensical puzzles- if you like tight, well-thought-out platforming, you've come to the right place.\nThrow in a second-thought plot and voice acting that sounds like it came from a high school play, and you've got Deadlight.

reviewText:
Trochę oklepana fabuła, plus nieskończone wątki prowadzące do nikąd, ale fajny klimat przez większość gry.

Fajnie wygląda - bardzo ładne tła zniszczonego przez apokalipsę zombi Seattle. Ambient w tle dodaje klimaciku.

Gierka trochę przypomina mi Limbo połączone lekko z The Last of Us.

Zabawy starczy na jakieś 3h, jak na tego typu grę jest to wystarczająco długo.

6/10 :)

reviewText: Altough i´m not a fan of zombie media, i have to say that this game is really good. It looks stunning and the story is great, creating an atmosphere much like half life. So good in fact, that you don´t even notice that you have to climb over obstacles, that you could easily circumvent if the world wasn´t 2D. It´s really sad that it suffers from the same problem many console ports and muti platform games suffer: akward and unresponsive controls. Jumping on and off things, especially when it has to be quick, made me almost break my keyboard multiple time and having to press shift and w too run and then press ctrl too roll is really akward. I haven´t tried using an xbox controller but that´s no excuse for not adapting the controls to the platform. I´d say if you want too play it try a controller or prepare to get your jimmies rustled.\n\nfinal verdict: story/visuals 9/10, controls 3/10

reviewText:
Deadlight has a surprising amount of detail and polish for a game of this nature. While it is rather short (approx 4 hrs), for $3.74 it was well worth it. If you like platformers, have a zombie fetish, or like the art style, you should really play this.

Pros-
- Parkour + zombies
- Generally smooth and intuitive controls
- Detailed environments
- Nice art style
- The ending was somewhat unsatisfying (my personal opinion, not everyone will agree)

Cons-
- If you are looking for a combat heavy game this is not it
- Mediocre voice acting
- Some minor bugs
- A few frustrating segments
- Nothing surprising. The gameplay is consistent through the entire experience. There are no (significant) new mechanics introduced for the majority of the game.

reviewText: Excellent game, story driven with an enthralling narrative and innovative gameplay. Be warned though, some puzzles are repetitve and sometimes the controls will leave you swearing. If you play with a gamepad you will fare much better than with keyboard & mouse. The repetitiveness can dole down the excellent atmosphere the game generates (a scary scene you play for the 5th time is a little less scary) but the same goes for any platformer. I love games with narrators - I'm looking at you Bastion - and this one does not disappoint. I was hooked after my first minute of play and did not really stop before I had finished it. The game is a bit short but the quality more than makes up for it. If you can get it in special it is really worth your money - and your time.\n\n8.5 / 10.

reviewText:
Some men are Dead to Rights. Others are Dead to Lights. And then a few still, who lack the proper character limits, are Deadlight. This is a story of a man who is Deadlight.

In Deadlight, you play as a man with a beard who is looking for his family. He talks to other survivors, and then zombies kill them and he kills the zombies. There are flashback scenes, and grittily stylized 2D motion comic cutscenes. Eventually the zombies are replaced with the worst kind of men--mad men. They are even worse than the underground platforming dungeons of the rat men who literally call themselves The Rat in an epic blunder clearly lacking any degree of subtlety or self-awareness. There is no subtlety in this world. Only death. Memento mori. RIP.

But during all of this thrilling and very thoughtful storytelling, there is something... wrong. There is something off about this whole experience. Maybe you don't realize it yet, but the main character does, slowly. As the story progresses and things reach their ultimate conclusion, all is suddenly brought to light and the darkest innermost secret of the world is revealed.

You bought a bad video game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Deadlight is a beautifully designed game with a rich story.  In terms of platformers, this game was a lot better than I expected, especially from a graphically point of view.  But the real let down is the control system.

I have been playing with my Xbox controller, and so often, especially in the middle region of the game, where timing your moves is so important, the control system just fails to deliver.  The game often doesn't respond to your commands when you make them, or you have to pickup a gun and immediately use, but you loose a precious 1 or 2 seconds while a specific cut scene plays its course, in which case you're dead.  This ruins and otherwise amazing game.  Even with that said, I my loads of frustration, its stillworth getting on a sale.

6.5/10

reviewText: When I first started Deadlight, I was instantly captivated by the atmosphere it created. Then it introduced clunky combat, and I thought, oh well, it's a zombie game, so I should feel weak and uncoordinated. I kept playing, and realized, no wait, this game is just sadistic. Jumping puzzles that require you to stand in exactly the right place, running sequences that require you to guess where the developer put traps, nonsensical puzzles- if you like tight, well-thought-out platforming, you've come to the right place.\nThrow in a second-thought plot and voice acting that sounds like it came from a high school play, and you've got Deadlight.

reviewText:
A really nice game - Great story line, graphics and use of environment.
The levels are well planned and do not become repetative which I find side-scrollers can become very fast.
The characters in the game are also well thought out and have a good depth of back story which adds largely to the game world.
Game play is generally good and fluent. The fast-paced paths work well and the player is required to work when running through the environments however there are some snag which which got me pretty frustrated.

There are several cons:

As mentioned above, the fast-paced stages are let down by snagging which become frustrating when in a chase.
Example: running from a chopper and the player gets keeps volting the same fence instead of dismounting.

A few of the controls do not make sense & feels like the Keyboard controls were shoehorned in after being designed for a gane pad.
Example: you have to hold shift and somehow hit control at the same time to roll.

The melee weapons are vitually useless. You can not tactically kill a hord if you are using a melee - believe me, I tried.

The pick-up-item is far to slow for the pace of the game. Many occations I have stopped to pick something up and by the time I have been given control of my character again, I am dead.

The above cons are not big deals. I do think using a game pad would stop the repeated volting on fences - it would also solve my issue with the control issue. The melee part only really became aparent a few times in the game where I was forced to fight.

Overall a good game. I would play through with a controller next time.

7/10

reviewText: Deadlight's biggest appeal is its great visual style and atmosphere. Everything looks excellent and there's a good amount of depth to each location to help break up the 2D side-scroller feel. You play a character named Randall, who's been separated from his friends and family and is looking for them. The storyline is pretty throw-away. Around the 2/3 mark the game really starts to lose steam and resorts to some pretty cheap instant death traps and timed segments that rely on precision jumping skills. Unfortunately, the game's controls aren't quite as precise as they need to be to accomplish these sections without dying repeatedly due to your character being unresponsive to your inputs. More than a few times Randall will just stay attached to a wall or fence, refusing to jump, despite the jump button being pressed repeatedly. This gets really frustrating really fast. It's a pretty short game too, only taking a few hours to complete. I'd recommend picking it up if you can get it for $5 or less. Overall, I'd give it a 6/10.

reviewText: An enjoyable title that is a cross between Prince of Persia, zombies, horror survival, and light puzzles. Story was handled well, characters and story are introduced by flashback or by optional diary entries that were interesting to read. Other collectables confer modest stat bonuses, or other little trinkets you can dig through later for additional world story. Completionist items are there for people who want them, including a time rush leaderboard.\n\nTequilla Works made a world detailed enough to be 3D but kept it in two Ds, published by Microsoft Studios but doesn't use GFWL, and created a well polished game that restrains itself to offering fresh scenarios every few minutes.

reviewText:
Do you like zombie games?  Do you like classic platform games like the original Prince of Persia or Out of this World?  Then you'll love Deadlight.   Deadlight is amazing.

The background art, atmosphere, and soundtrack  in this game are awesome.  I was totally immersed in this cliche zombie apocalypse story because it's so well done and executed.

Each chapter begins and ends with a comic book style cinematic that set the stage for the level.  The platforming puzzles are fun and challenging without ever feeling impossible or too simplistic.  The zombie combat is mostly a puzzle too, since this is a platform game and not side-scroll shooter.

I really enjoyed this, and rate it a must play for fans of Limbo or the previous mentioned classics.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Deadlight is very good game, overhall it gets an 8.5 out of 10 (imho).
It has a great atmosphere, and an extraordinary level-design.
The game is quite challenging, and it gives you the right level of cliffhanger. During the playthrough you will feel the anxiety, the adrenaline and the need to hold on. You will learn that fighting with all your forces is not the only way to stay alive, in fact you will discover the power of hope. The story-line as you probably have already understood is enjoyable.
The downsides of this games are its longevity and some sporadic annoying physic bugs.
The story-line last from 4 to 5 hours, than you unlock a new (more difficult) story mode, and it can last longer if you decide to obtain all the available achievement, but it is definitely short. About the bugs, at least they don't show up while playing (except for this one time that I find myself standing on a ledge and the zombies keept crossing from one side to the other side of the ledge without beeing able to catch me), but they happen with dead-bodies collisions. They aren't that annoying but you know... they are there!
In the end Deadlight is a great game, even more if you consider buying it on sale, for a little cost you will have a valuable product.

On one hand, the atmosphere, imagination, and style of the game remind me very much of Prince of Persia.

On the other, the exceptionally fiddly controls (and poor control layout) and the idiosyncratic jumping style remind me very much of Prince of Persia.

reviewText:
This one never decides if it wants to punish you or reward you for avoiding combat. The melee options are clunky and awful which I do really like, but the shooting trivializes the challenge in the end segments where you have unlimited ammo. You're always pinpoint accurate and reloading isn't that big a deal. Also any atmosphere that the game tries to build up as being somewhat based in reality goes out the window when the character you play as does super human feats often at times when his life is not in immediate danger.

It just feels like for every good idea they had, they paid for with two bad ones. Also the main character's voice actor is trying really hard to do a Steve Blum impersonation which irks me as Steve Blum isn't that amazing to begin with.

Give this one a pass.

reviewText: Picked this up on sale for cheap.  Fun platformer with great graphics and a solid atmosphere. reviewText:
Yes, I recommend Deadlight.

reviewText:
Deadlight is a pretty good game. Good story, gameplay, graphics are decent for a sidescrolling 3D game, etc. etc.

I shouldn't have to talk about it being a post-apocalyptic game, there tons of those now these days as it is, how does it compare to others? Well it doesn't particularly stand out. It's not overly outlandish but at least it's not I Am Alive, which sucked.

I guess my biggest gripe with this game is, well there's two things, one being the cut scenes. I can understand an indie studio wanting to focus on gameplay and perhaps because they were short on time, they opted for motion graphics. Yet some of the cutscenes are still fully 3D so the mixture of those felt awkward and out of place. This game never came off as being comic bookish. My other issue was something menial, the fact that zombies paths are suddenly blocked when they could just as easily go around that object seeing as most of the zombies in the game come towards you from the background anyway.

Those are really my only two complaints, otherwise, pretty good indie game. Great level design. Etc. Etc.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Rating 7.5/10

What is it?
2d sidescroller action/platformer

The Good:

+ Graphically the game looks fantastic with some great backgrounds that highten the atmosphere

+ Overall the game does a good job of changing the pace and the enviroments keeping things varied

+Good mix of action and platforming segments

+Music adds to the atmosphere

+Easy achievements except for nightmare mode

The Bad:

- The controls are a bit....'iffy', a lot of needless deaths are going to happen because you wanted to jump straight up and you jumped into the gap.

- Trial and error platforming that doesn't really fit into the game, occurs more often in the later part of the game leading to a lot of frustration.

-The voice acting and dialogue is atrociously bad

Conclusion:

At first I didn't know why this game was getting bad reviews, it starts off decent enough and looks like it keeps getting better. However the more you play the more flaws begin to appear. The controls are a bit too stiff given the platforming the game requires you to do and their was one segment of the game where it really tests your limits near the end. Despite all that, I enjoyed the game, I thought it was worth it alone just to see the enironments and artwork that went into the game.

reviewText: So, I don't get all the hate towards the game, there is no such thing as a bad game, just a bad price, the price might be a bit hefty, but for all the work that went into creating the games atmosphere and sound design/soundtrack, it is worth it, It just gives you this feel of dread constantly and there are a lot of heartpumping moments of tension, the controls might be a bit clunky, but you will get used to them quickly, this game is a work of art, mixed with some decent gameplay and puzzles. 8.5/10

reviewText:
70%

You are Randall, a badass survivor looking for his family: a man who seemingly knows pain and loss in a 1980's zombie apocalypse. Deadlight holds itself as a puzzle platformer, with Assassin’s Creed jumps and traps galore. Think Prince of Persia meets The Walking Dead, and throw in a few traps for fun. Although the game is pretty short, taking me around 5 hours to beat; it makes up for it in ingenuity and atmosphere.

The story is touching, Randall – you – is searching for his wife and daughter amidst the chaos of the end times. The real enemy beyond the zombies is a group of renegades who call themselves “The New Law”. They are a sadistic group who take delight in torturing and killing innocent survivors. Separated from his survivor group at the beginning, Randall’s journey will introduce him to The New Law but he will still meet a few new friends on the way.

1980’s Seattle is really a beautiful setting (besides the dead people and destruction). The HUD is very non-intrusive with only a small health and stamina bar, leaving plenty of screen space for the visual delights. The background looks amazing: varying between dark gritty cityscapes, dark gritty warehouses, or even a dark gritty sewer. Okay, there’s not a lot of variety in setting, but it’s so pretty you won’t even care. The environment can be shiny and heavy with rain, or even have a crumbling building in the background, all-in-all the effects employed are beautiful.

The lighting can come from lonely street lamps or neon lights: giving the zombies a Christmassy glow. This isn’t the zombie game where you’re a one man killing machine; these zombies will tear you apart if you get more than two at once, so you really want to run away. The sounds of these shambling “Shadows” (as the game calls them) is quite unnerving. You never know if a dead body you pass may climb up and greet you. The music isn’t too intrusive, but makes use of classic horror “creepy ambiance” sounds: a DUN DUN at a surprise, a constant hum to build suspense in an area, or just some soft music to add a somber mood. Speaking of ambiance, the almost constant downpour in Rain City adds a serious tone to the usual jubilance of constantly fighting for survival against hordes of the undead. Our protagonist’s gravelly, serious voice guides us through this desolate world and feels comforting, always calm in the face of tragedy.


The gameplay and controls typically feels pretty solid, the controls being standard for keyboard controls, with the option for a USB Xbox controller. The aiming is tight and straightforward, and the platforming is what you’re used to with Assassin’s Creed or Prince of Persia. A large problem is when trying to jump vertically, sometimes Randall won’t grab the ledge unless in the exact right spot or he’ll just jump forward into a puddle of electricity or horde of zombies.

When backed into a corner, Randall can fend off the horde with a fire axe or a few different guns discovered throughout the story. The first gun you get is a revolver, and it takes Randall into a flashback to his first time with a gun and learning to shoot, giving a tutorial without it feeling like a classroom lecture, quite refreshing. Later on, you unlock a shotgun and an assault rifle, both useful for clearing a pesky zombie horde when running isn’t an option.

Overall, Deadlight is a great story driven game -- If relatively short -- and offers an interesting perspective on the zombie apocalypse, running away taking priority to fighting, and with the climbing and jumping elements. Where Deadlight really shines is the environment. The broken city and serious tones give the setting the perfect mood to combine with danger and a feeling of loss. A game as colorful as it is lighthearted, I definitely recommend spending $15 -- or less if you wait for a Steam sale -- to experience this game, whether for the compelling story or the amazing atmosphere.

reviewText:
I love this type side scrolling platformer/action game, it reminds me of Trine.  Despite the played out zombie genre the game is interesting enough.  It falls short in a few areas though.

The controls are sloppy for interacting with the environment.  You'll often find yourself swinging over the top of a fence a few times before ended up where you want to me.  The game honestly feels like a poor console port as far as controls go.

The event triggering is hit or miss.  I had to reload the first area from checkpoint after I passed the ambulance because I could not progress to the next area, the character would simply run into an invisible wall.  I've experienced similar issues three times now.

After leaving the Rat and the sewers, and after running from the helicopter the kid says something like 'Why didn't you shoot them?' in a cutscene, when I never even got my revolver back after it was taken by the Rat.  The following area has a lock that needs to be shot and since I'm apparently supposed to have a revolver but do not, I'm stuck.

I can deal with a bug here or there but this game is simply unfinished. I gave up on the game at that point.

This is the product of lazy development and poor quality control.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I want to start by saying that, me not recommending this game, has nothing to do with the game itself per se. It’s the pc port that it’s just awful and makes it unbearable to play (for me at least) as it stands at the moment.

I’ve had constant slowdowns, hiccups, freezes, crashes, you name it.

If the bugs and issues get solved with patching I’ll get right back to it, but until then it’s a big no no for me.

For the game itself I really was enjoying the ambience and story up to the point that I’m at.
The game mechanics (combat/plaforming) rely on stamina management which make you feel really vulnerable adding up to the immersion. You’re not going to rambo your way out of tight situations, you need to think and act fast, that’s the motto.
Although the game is only sidescrolling, it never felt linear nor boring even there being no choice of path to take. It presents you with such a variety of situations that it makes the lack of choice secondary since you get so immersed in it.

Just to end it, I really wish they fix performance issues because I want to play the full experience, not the bugged one :(

Not all hope is lost, since we’ve seen this before with pc ports of XBLA games like this one.
Magicka for instance suffered from lots of issues when it came out on pc, now runs smooth as butter.

reviewText:
This would be a really enjoyable game if it actually worked properly. I don't know if it's because it was ported poorly or if it really does just have horrible mechanics, but they're there either way. There are also a LOT of glitches, audio, graphical, and wall-clipping alike. The story and voice acting were painfully bad at times. But the combat was the thing that annoyed me the most. Zombies will straight up cheat sometimes and instantly stand up after you knock them over; your character will turn around for NO REASON mid-battle and swing away in the wrong direction; zombies can move on the z axis while you can't, which looks neat, but offers them the opportunity to attack you while you can't attack them. Also, I don't think I've ever played a game where I liked the main character less.

Despite the many, MANY things that annoyed me, I did enjoy parts of this game a lot. The beginning is especially good. The sewer part I didn't mind as much as everyone else seems to (though I have a thing for run-down industrial aesthetic, plus it reminded me of LIMBO). The end bit was the worst to me. The art was beautiful throughout, and the music was nice. Some of the puzzles were quite fun.

All-in-all, a game that could have been great, but is instead frustrating, buggy, and not at all worth the asking price. Get it on sale if you must, but don't expect much.

reviewText: Deadlight is among my top 10 favorite games. The atmosphere in this terrific game is intoxicating, voice acting is great, the scenery is gorgeous, and the story will keep you coming back time after time until you finish. There's a perfect mix of tense action, puzzle solving, and quiet down moments.\n\nGameplay consists of simple platforming and challenging combat. However combat is so discouraged in the game that it's almost always better to avoid the Shadows than to actually confront them, which only makes every forced encouter a hair raising experience. Unfortunately, there are some frustrating trial and error" times where you might have to restart 5 times to get it right. This breaks the atmosphere and absorbing nature of the game
date: but not enough to make it an experience changer.\n\nI cannot say enough about the art direction of this game. The background is truly the star here. To just pause for a moment and look at what's behind you is sometimes breathtaking. This is a beautiful game. The music is also fantastic
recommended: which is actually best experienced by just sitting at the main menu and listening. The cut scenes are drawn comic pages with something moving in them. This is slightly offputting as the rest of the game is so gorgeous
hoursPlayed: it would seem that the cutscenes deserved more love and attention than they received. However the great voice acting makes up for most of this.\n\nThe story follows Randal Wayne as he attempts to find and save his wife and daughter while alos taking care of other survivors he's grown close to. The story is gripping and sometimes heartbreaking
voteText: with a ending that is completely out of the blue; I never saw it coming. The game somehow manages to change your entire perspective on the main character and the game itself
helpfulPercent:
all in one final extremely well put together cut scene.

So should you buy it?
The answer to this comes with a question: are you a gamer who plays for the experience or for the simple purpose of playing a game? If you enjoy an immersing experience
votesHelpful: then by all means this is for you. However if you only play games because of good gameplay (COD
votesTotal: TF2) but not because of the story or experience they present
votesFunny:
you might find yourself bored.

Synopsis:
Deadlight is a fantastic EXPERIENCE. Gameplay may lack in a few areas
commentsCount: but overall Deadlight is a beautiful game that deserves all the hype it has recieved."

For the game itself I really was enjoying the ambience and story up to the point that I’m at.
The game mechanics (combat/plaforming) rely on stamina management which make you feel really vulnerable adding up to the immersion. You’re not going to rambo your way out of tight situations, you need to think and act fast, that’s the motto.
Although the game is only sidescrolling, it never felt linear nor boring even there being no choice of path to take. It presents you with such a variety of situations that it makes the lack of choice secondary since you get so immersed in it.

Just to end it, I really wish they fix performance issues because I want to play the full experience, not the bugged one :(

Not all hope is lost, since we’ve seen this before with pc ports of XBLA games like this one.
Magicka for instance suffered from lots of issues when it came out on pc, now runs smooth as butter.

reviewText:
70%

You are Randall, a badass survivor looking for his family: a man who seemingly knows pain and loss in a 1980's zombie apocalypse. Deadlight holds itself as a puzzle platformer, with Assassin’s Creed jumps and traps galore. Think Prince of Persia meets The Walking Dead, and throw in a few traps for fun. Although the game is pretty short, taking me around 5 hours to beat; it makes up for it in ingenuity and atmosphere.

The story is touching, Randall – you – is searching for his wife and daughter amidst the chaos of the end times. The real enemy beyond the zombies is a group of renegades who call themselves “The New Law”. They are a sadistic group who take delight in torturing and killing innocent survivors. Separated from his survivor group at the beginning, Randall’s journey will introduce him to The New Law but he will still meet a few new friends on the way.

1980’s Seattle is really a beautiful setting (besides the dead people and destruction). The HUD is very non-intrusive with only a small health and stamina bar, leaving plenty of screen space for the visual delights. The background looks amazing: varying between dark gritty cityscapes, dark gritty warehouses, or even a dark gritty sewer. Okay, there’s not a lot of variety in setting, but it’s so pretty you won’t even care. The environment can be shiny and heavy with rain, or even have a crumbling building in the background, all-in-all the effects employed are beautiful.

The lighting can come from lonely street lamps or neon lights: giving the zombies a Christmassy glow. This isn’t the zombie game where you’re a one man killing machine; these zombies will tear you apart if you get more than two at once, so you really want to run away. The sounds of these shambling “Shadows” (as the game calls them) is quite unnerving. You never know if a dead body you pass may climb up and greet you. The music isn’t too intrusive, but makes use of classic horror “creepy ambiance” sounds: a DUN DUN at a surprise, a constant hum to build suspense in an area, or just some soft music to add a somber mood. Speaking of ambiance, the almost constant downpour in Rain City adds a serious tone to the usual jubilance of constantly fighting for survival against hordes of the undead. Our protagonist’s gravelly, serious voice guides us through this desolate world and feels comforting, always calm in the face of tragedy.


The gameplay and controls typically feels pretty solid, the controls being standard for keyboard controls, with the option for a USB Xbox controller. The aiming is tight and straightforward, and the platforming is what you’re used to with Assassin’s Creed or Prince of Persia. A large problem is when trying to jump vertically, sometimes Randall won’t grab the ledge unless in the exact right spot or he’ll just jump forward into a puddle of electricity or horde of zombies.

When backed into a corner, Randall can fend off the horde with a fire axe or a few different guns discovered throughout the story. The first gun you get is a revolver, and it takes Randall into a flashback to his first time with a gun and learning to shoot, giving a tutorial without it feeling like a classroom lecture, quite refreshing. Later on, you unlock a shotgun and an assault rifle, both useful for clearing a pesky zombie horde when running isn’t an option.

Overall, Deadlight is a great story driven game -- If relatively short -- and offers an interesting perspective on the zombie apocalypse, running away taking priority to fighting, and with the climbing and jumping elements. Where Deadlight really shines is the environment. The broken city and serious tones give the setting the perfect mood to combine with danger and a feeling of loss. A game as colorful as it is lighthearted, I definitely recommend spending $15 -- or less if you wait for a Steam sale -- to experience this game, whether for the compelling story or the amazing atmosphere.

reviewText:
A truly atmospheric and gripping adventure through a post apocalyptic Washington during a fictional zombie outbreak in the 1980's.

The first thing I noticed about Deadlight was how nice it looked. Being a platformer, I expected a more two dimensional approach but utilizing the Unreal Engine 3, they managed to pull off a fully 3D experience whilst retaining the old school platforming style. The lighting, animations, and effects really bring the game to life and have all been made to a very high standard.

I honestly couldn’t stop playing Deadlight at some parts. The story and characters kept me interested and I was always looking forward to the next level. The game does well to keep your interest by becoming increasingly cinematic. Flashbacks, dream sequences, strong cut scenes, all do well to make you feel like you’re part of a long film with a beginning, a middle, and an end.

There was a significant problem with Deadlight though.  I fully completed the game (with the exception of nightmare mode) over a 2 day period of about 7.5 hours. Roughly 5-6 hours in campaign length, on hard difficulty. There were parts I had to do over and over again and several areas where I just stopped and looked around.  So some people might have even beaten it in even less time. The game does warrant a second playthrough, but the Nightmare mode is proving to be too difficult for me. Playing through the entire game without any checkpoints and perma-death is balls.

So Deadlight is a great game. Solid story, interesting gameplay, and very visually appealing. I only wish they made the story that little bit longer as I didn't want it to end so soon.

reviewText: Beautiful but tedious atmospheric platformer. Can't tell whether it wants a grizzled survivalist cliche or shell shocked family man for its protagonist, so our guy is awkwardly both. Deadlight's buggy controls let down genuinely suspenseful moments, where gloriously orchestrated frustration and desperation get drowned out by the more pressing tale of man against his keyboard.\n\nThe main issue though is that the poor devs didn't realize that in games like this, less can be more- take out the cut scenes and dialogue and let the player fill in the blanks. We can be clever like that. Worked for Limbo, would've worked here. If they'd given us some credit we might've had an arthouse Jacob's Ladder for the zombie age.

reviewText:
Splain’s View – For the full video review with gameplay click below

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PNTbisM0nuY


Introduction - Deadlight is a brilliantly illustrated single player game that takes place in a zombie filled, post-apocalyptic Seattle in the 1980s. However it is not your typical modern zombie game by. It is a platformer, that at first touch, feels very Odd World meets Prince of Persia. You are playing as a man who is in search for his family amidst the chaos that was Seattle. Along his journey you can find diary entries of his past that are very interesting to read. You can also find many other tidbits about the world you are in, including radio broadcast, television broadcast and notes left by once survivors. You are limited in weapons and ammo, forcing you to play smart, using the environment to your advantage in a very parkour manor. This is where the game really shines. While the environment can help you, they can also hurt (usually kill) you. The gameplay is all played out in dramatic fashion which equals the best action scenes of any movies.  You will most likely die often, but that is okay, there are many save points so you can try and try again. You can expect to beat the game in 5-6 hours. Now for the ratings.

1.	Story - 8/10 The story is done very well in this game. You can flesh it out by playing through the game and finding diary entries along with other reports hidden in the game. None of them are handed to you though, so make the most of your exploring if you really want to learn more! The diary entries mostly fill you in on the character you play, which helps explain his personality and motivations.  After each (level?) there is a cut-scene drawn out in a very unique style, which fits the mood of the game. It is a great story which makes you feel your purpose in the world while also giving you an attachment to your character.

2.	Difficulty – 8/10 This game is very hard. I doubt anyone has beaten it without dying a few dozen times. The good news is no game over and many save points in which you will restart from. Many areas of the game seem to be trial and error, and often I felt I had accomplished something great when I would beat something on the first try. The difficulty adds a challenge to this game which is very rewarding, not just at the end of the game, but at each save point!

3.	Visuals – 9/10 This is probably the most subjective area of the game. If you are not into platformers you would probably rate this around a 6. But being a platformer the graphics and animations throughout the game are top notch! When you dive through a window or bust through a door it is a completely satisfying and entertaining to see. The zombies in the background you see will often run right up onto screen after you, which is terrifying when you see dozens in the background. And I can’t forget about the environment in general. The post-apocalyptic Seattle in makes you truly feel that it is the end of days.

4.	Audio – 7/10 Some of the voice acting in the game is great, especially the lead narrator, but some of it is sub-par. Also some lines are scripted perfectly while some come in at awkward times depending on how fast you are going through the scene. The sound effects in the game  are about average.

5.	Gameplay – 7/10 The gameplay is very fast paced through much of the game. The motions of your character as you control him through huge stunts make you feel like you are on a very epic scale and you usually are! However there are times when the controls feel a bit clunky and they actually got me killed more times than I would care to admit. This did not ruin the game at all though, it would probably be better played with an X-box controller as opposed to a keyboard ( I went keyboard).

6.	The Final Verdict – 8/10 This is an entertaining story in a very beautiful post- apocalyptic Seattle. It is great as a platformer and makes you play with strategy. It is very easy to die, but not particularly a hard game to beat because of the consistent save points. It is very rewarding each time you reach one of these save points and typically entices you to play though to the next one to see how you make it out or if you even will. The character development is done well through inserts in the game, the narrative and the cut-scenes. The gameplay is animated beautifully but the controls sometimes get in the way. There is not too much replay value, but you can unlock a hard mode after beating the game. Overall it was a great experience. I would definitely recommend this game if you come across it on a decent sale.

reviewText:
This is the first game in a long time I've played that's so good, I've been sucked in and played for hours straight. I'm not sure if this is a compliment to the devs or not, but upon playing for a while, all I could think of is it's like someone finally re-invented Abe's Odessy, except with fantastic visuals, story line and character development, all with the same type of puzzle solving. Little additions like the guns, physics, and other small details really add to a game like this and make it stand out.

All that said, there's a few niggles here and there. If you're playing without a controller, you can run into some frustrating issues such as rolling being ctrl + shift + a/d. Rather hard to press all those at the same time. Also you can end up swapping sides on a fence/ladder by accident just by continuing to try going the same direction...

These small issues aside, the devs on this one really made a fantastic game, I would easily recommend this to anyone.

reviewText:
Rating 7.5/10

What is it?
2d sidescroller action/platformer

The Good:

+ Graphically the game looks fantastic with some great backgrounds that highten the atmosphere

+ Overall the game does a good job of changing the pace and the enviroments keeping things varied

+Good mix of action and platforming segments

+Music adds to the atmosphere

+Easy achievements except for nightmare mode

The Bad:

- The controls are a bit....'iffy', a lot of needless deaths are going to happen because you wanted to jump straight up and you jumped into the gap.

- Trial and error platforming that doesn't really fit into the game, occurs more often in the later part of the game leading to a lot of frustration.

-The voice acting and dialogue is atrociously bad

Conclusion:

At first I didn't know why this game was getting bad reviews, it starts off decent enough and looks like it keeps getting better. However the more you play the more flaws begin to appear. The controls are a bit too stiff given the platforming the game requires you to do and their was one segment of the game where it really tests your limits near the end. Despite all that, I enjoyed the game, I thought it was worth it alone just to see the enironments and artwork that went into the game.

reviewText: Cool game. Reminds me of LIMBO. Light puzzling, platforming and gunplay elements. Be prepared to die. Constantly. I spent 50% of my first playthrough redoing the same sections over and over, up to a dozen times. Fortunately the game checkpoints every five feet, so you don't feel like a total jackhole for getting eviscerated, shot, impaled, drowned, electrocuted, and falling to your death every time you enter a new room. Warm, fuzzy storyline tackles themes of genocide, ♥♥♥♥, child murder, suicide, right-wing paranoia, and a world lacking any semblance of personal hygene. Did I mention it's family friendly? In conclusion: Killer art design, but little else.\n\nGet it on sale.

reviewText:
I don't know if this game is good or not but I bought it and I can't play it.

A few remarks:

1. Good graphics doesn't mean good game. If your game doesn't have options to accomodate even the worst computers then you're making a bad game.

2. Don't ever make a game in the unreal engine that requires usage of the mouse. This goes for dungeon defenders too. The unreal engine is not made for the mouse. What you get is a hacky laggy sprite on your screen which moves as you move your mouse--except about 2 seconds behind.

So would I recommend this game? No. If I could get a refund I would. Not just because my computers (all new within a year or two) can't handle it, but also because of the stupid mouse lag.

reviewText: 5/10\n\nDeadlight started out strong. It had good graphics, a dark story and the obvious pull of apocalyptic zombie outbreaks. But after about an hour and a half, I hit the stage with the Rat man, a convoluted mess of deadly contrapations. I became very annoyed with the unresponsive controls. I continued playing, hoping it would regain its appeal but it was in vain. I ended up finishing the game just to say I had and I was not sorry to say goodbye.

reviewText:
This game is a chore.  After a couple of hours I found myself only doing it for the achievements and after a couple more I just couldn't continue and deleted it.  I was lured in by a great looking environment.  However, the story is wooden and trite.  Based only on the dialoge you'd think the audience was 7 year olds if not for the grim backdrop.

Gameplay starts out interesting, but is incredibly unforgiving.  You hardly kill any zombies.  The axe tires you out before you can kill more than one zombie (rarely will there only be one) and bullets are too scarce (and often have to be used to shoot a lock).  Yet the game makes you run through zombie groups repeatedly and this can't be avoided.

The environment is full of (1) things you need to jump over and (2) background that is irrelevant.  So you will stumble over a box you didn't realize needed to be jumped and be eaten.   You will come upon a hole in the fence that you can't see and need to crouch through but you try to jump and will be eaten.  So, you get to repeat segments over and over to guess your way though.  Randall is slow to boot.  Being forced along pell mell means you'll miss all the interesting side bits.

I wanted to like this game, but I did not.  I cannot explain its (too high) metascore (which was one of the reasons I bought it) nor do I understand the positive reviews from players (The Royal Nonesuch" comes to mind that purchasers don't wish to look foolish on how they spent their money).  This game is not fun or interesting.  Anyone who want's to see how pretty it is should just go watch a youtube walkthrough for a much more satisfying experience."

reviewText: It was a fun little platformer. Despite being set in a zombie apocalypse I didn't find this game scary at all. Even on Nightmare mode, the only time I ever felt fear of something it was fear of insta-kill stuff that meant I'd have to re-do several levels (it gets tedious and frustrating). Speaking of Nightmare mode, I finally got the Achievement after fighting through it almost an entire day. During the quest I admit it got really demoralizing at times but now that it's over I can say it harkens back to the 80s and 90s games that had no quicksaves (and no achievements). It's been a while since I've really had to work at an Achievement but today I certainly did. Still sucked though.

reviewText:
Deadlight for me is one of the best indie titles i have played. The story and the pace of this post apocalyptic zombie title are one of the best out there. There arent many zombie games that will make you understand and feel what its like to live and survive in a post apocalyptic world, where every ounce of humanity people have, has been discarded for the sole purpose of survival. Its a game that builds on those emotions, especially during the cutscenes were we can witness first hand what it means to be both a hero and a villain.

The game contains stunning  visuals as well that combined with an awesome soundtrack provide an even more immersive experience to the world and daily life of the main char. A main char whose story begins with the usual cliche of finding his family but as the game progresses it becomes so much more than that. Every arc is building up for the ultimate conclusion, which trust me is one i enjoyed to the fullest.

The gameplay for the most part plays smoothly and without many shortcomings. You must for the better part use your brain rather than your muscles. Its easier to avoid the zombies rather than to fight them, but when you have to fight the combat itself is not so difficult. There are some bugs concerning the way you move and how you face the zombies themselves but that wont be an issue after a while. The puzzles themselves arent that hard, but they have their moments especially during the end, where you have to show that you mastered everything the game has taught you in order to survive.

To sum up this was a game that i loved from the beginning to end. I recommend it to all zombie fans and indie lovers.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A sidescroller platformer game using 3D models, originally imported from the Xbox LIVE Arcade program. See it like an indie game, especially since it's rather short.

Pros
* A strong atmosphere, the mixing of 2D gameplay with 3D graphics is done well and Seattle is rendered as a dark and haunting place

Cons
* Finicky controls, a big problem when swinging your axe is often the best way to defend yourself
* After the middle part of the game, there will be so many instakilling situations that you will wonder why they even bothered with a health system, especially considering the lack of responsiveness of the main character
* The voice acting isn't really convincing

Ultimately, despite its good intentions the game becomes way too frustrating after the middle part. One can only feel like all the unfair deaths were added to pad out the otherwise very short story.
voteText: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Deadlight is an interesting little 2D Side scrolling, Zombie Survival game, where you solve puzzles, overcome obstacles, and try not to get overwhelmed by zombies. You can pick up melee weapons as well as ranged for protection, but avoiding a fight is preferrable if you want to survive. You have to manage not only health, but stamina as well, and can find power-ups along the way to help you out. There are also hidden items on the different levels you can collect. By doing this you unlock players diary entries, as well as other goodies and easter eggs.\n\nI've played a lot of different 2D side scrollers over the years and this one visually looks nice, but the puzzles are overly simple and could have been more complex. It is still fun to play regardless, and should be given a try if it's on sale or part of a bundle.

reviewText:
8/10

I was disappointed because I couldn't play Dying Light. Because I missed out on the fun zombie land parkour gameplay. But then I found Dead Light.. which I guess is the after math to dying light that is no longer dying.. so its dead? Yes? No? Carrots?

Anyway, The game your first playthrough will take 3-4 hours only. So I suggest you get it on a good sale. Once you learn the levels puzzles it will take you maybe 1 1/2 to 2 hours only. But it is still really fun to dash through. Even if you think you can't die, 1 miss step can pretty much end you.

The controls can be a bit.. wonky once in a while, I use a xbox controller so worst I get is my guy will jump forward when I wanted to go up instead.

The story is interesting and easy to follow.

My real complaints for the game in itself, is that only 2 cutscenes seem to have sound, the rest go silent(luckily the subtitles are enabled by default.) and the framerate will suddenly drop randomly at certain spots. Despite having no rain or enemies around at the moment.

I also wish fighting zombies would be a bit easier, if you make the wrong step or fail to stay above them, you could get cornered and kill quickly.. They also give a tackle ability that only gets you hurt and grabbed. So not sure why it is even in the game.

I have beat it 4 times now, but I have yet to complete it 100%. Once you beat the story, you unlock a new mode. Nightmare mode, in this mode if you die once back to the start. There may be some checkpoints SOMEWHERE but I haven't seen any yet.

Forcing you to replay over and over till you pretty much master every section perfectly.

So to recap. Wonderful game, amazing gameplay, and despite being so short, tons of replays can be done without being bored.
Find a good sale, and give it a try.

Issues:
Poor sound quality on cutscenes.
Framerate drop.
Controls can feel a bit off sometimes.
Combat is too against you, many mistakes aren't forgiven.

reviewText:
Product received for free

What's black and white, mixed with gothic environment and zombies all over it? That's right! It's Deadlight.
Deadlight is an action adventure platformer developed by Tequila Works, S.L. and published by Microsoft Studios in 2012. The game follows the journey of Randall Wayne, a man searching for his family that has drastically disappeared when the zombie apocalypse came out. The world of the game takes place around the year 1980 in the beautiful surroundings of the Seattle city. Because of an complication, Randall gets separated rather at the beggining of the game from the group of survivors that he was traveling with and spends most of the time trying to reunite with them and find a safe place in which to shelter from the horrors that will eventually find you through the course of the game.
When you actually start the game, you will know very little about what has been happening and the game throws you directly into the action but with time you’ll manage to find various journal entries that will slowly begin to shed some light on the horrifying events that have taken place since the end of the world started.
I have to warn you here. This is not your typical zombie game! Zombies are overpowered just as they should actually be in reality. You can only kill a few of them on the whole duration of the game so you should keep that in mind before buying the game because you will not find the Rambo style of killing zombies in Deadlight. The game encourages you to find ways of sneaking around them while continuing the journey of finding where your family is.

The game is based on the action-platformer genre at heart, but the driving story and the deeply environmental graphics makes it feel much like one of those adventures of Tomb Raider. Cinematics consists of motion comics with voice overs, which are more enjoyable than you think they would be. Randall will guide you through flashbacks of his past occasionally, making you understand the story better, and there are diary entries lying out there for you to find that will add more plot to the story, as well as some extra curiosities introduced by the ID of some strangers and newspaper clippings. Through the course of the game you will also find first aid kits lying around which will help you in the most appalling moments. And let’s not forget about the extra bullets that will save your life a few times. There are also a few handhelds" to be found between the chapters
date: which will unlock some nice games to play within the extras menu.\n\nThe controls for jumping can be a bit suffocating at times
recommended: but the auto-save function will ensure that you don't have to repeat much of the section if you’re used to the feeling of dying a lot while playing a game.\nThe game also introduces you to a lot of diversity

reviewText:
Good:
Really nice visuals, and a decent story.

Bad:
Hard to tell what's in the background as opposed to your current plane. It's a 2D game but the enemies sometimes come from the background and it's hard to tell at what point you can hit them. The gun combat is OK, but the melee is very poor, the hit detection seems to be a bit off much of the time. Occasionally unresponsive controls. Some cheesy deaths from the environment that can only be avoided if you've already tried it once.

Conclusion:
I'd give it a 5/10 at full price, but if you can get it for 5 bucks of less i'd probably bump it up to a 6/10. It had potential if they only tightened up the combat and made the background and foreground a little more distinctive.

reviewText: Frustrating mechanics. Laughably bad VA. Lackluster story. Outside of its setting and atmosphere (i'm a sucker for most anything dystopian/post-apocalyptic), this game has very few redeeming qualities.  I've heard that a lot of people had issues with the game's length; that really wasn't an issue for me. I beat it in about 3 hours, which felt about right for me. They really didn't have much to work with story wise to begin with, it all felt really thin. Anyway, not every game has to be 10+ hours padded with filler, endless backtracking, and other nonsense to be considered worthwhile.\n\nI'd only recommend this game if you can get it for cheap on sale like i did, or get it in a humble bundle type deal.

reviewText:
If you like dying a lot and also like being frustrated at times (Re-doing certain levels, sections), then this may be a good game for you.

Graphics and music are good , shame about the game mechanics

It's a Zombie platform game.
The Zombies are quite fast and your AXE feels like it's just for show.
I have yet to actually kill a zombie with it. Sure it knocks them down , for a bit, then they just get back up and yet they die from falls.
Also  it seems like a shotgun does no more damage than your pistol.

I would have liked if you could shoot their legs and jump over them instead of always going for the head.

But this game will appeal to some.
I fear I may just give up as this feels more like a dying simulator than a real enjoyable game.

reviewText:
The art style of this game is great: the silhouettes and cut-away scenery work really well.

However, I would not recommend this game to anyone, not even for £3/€3.

The rest of the game is lacklustre and an exercise in frustration in places. While the story and narrative are not great it's the controls that really let the game down. The movement of the character is slow and unresponsive which means that trying to do wall jumping, avoiding obstacles in the sewer section and running in the chase sections often results in a series of frustrated replays. As these are major parts of the game prepare for lots of reloading! In addition I found the game crashed periodically when I tried to open menus.

I gave it about 2 hours and played using an Xbox controller.

reviewText:
Overall this game is pretty fun, but I can't recommend a purchase unless on a deep discount.

The controls are very finnicky - there were many times where I could not jump off a fence correctly or my character would just randomly point the other way and jump.  The levels and puzzles are interesting but nothing that is going to stump you for very long.  In the later levels when there are swarms of bad guys, you'll go through tedious trial and error to memorize when things are going to come out at you and when you need to shoot at just the right time.

The graphics are well done.  During the cutscenes, everything is presented as a graphic novel.  The voice acting is pretty weak for the most part.  And the main story is pretty cliche while the nightmare/flashbacks are not used enough during the game. The end of the story was so painfully bad and had my eyes rolling so much that was thankful to be over (took roughly 3 hours to beat the main story) and could uninstall the game (which takes up over 4 gigs on the hdd).

reviewText: The game looks nice, but it's one of those games that wants you to die. A lot. There's visual trickery on just about every area so that you have to die a bunch before you figure out how to move on. Floors transition seamlessly into background images so that you fall to your death, and enemies often look like they're on the same plane as you, only to be just slightly off enough that you attack through them, then they get you from behind after taking one step to be on the same level as you are.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Unique environments
- Pleasing graphics

Cons:
- Horrific game physics/mechanics and layering
- Really bland story
- Can be infuriating

Deadlight's biggest issue with me is that it's getting me a lot more frustrated with it's trial-and-error-based gameplay, than letting me enjoy everything else. The shoddy game mechanics and physics can greatly impede your progress, leaving you in one short section of the map for a tedious half an hour. I'm usually pretty patient for puzzles and stretched gameplay, but this game had me literally hopping off my chair with frustration. I enjoyed it for the first hour, but then despised almost everything about it after the second.

I wouldn't recommend anyone spending $15 on this game.

reviewText:
Overall, it is a fun and different platform game. For the price that you pay you can not complain much about the game. It's a mixture of fast / slow pace platforms with a mixture of combat and sometimes puzzle aspects.

I often found this game to be infuriating when it came the use of combat. Hit rates are not done well and is soo easy to die and get sent back to an earlier check point if you find yourself fighting 3+ zombies.

Also, it was so easy to accidently do a jump you was not planning on doing.. i.e. trying to jump upwards (where most would detect this is what you are doing) it would instead make you jump accross into what ever area (often ending in death..)

However, with this in mind, it is worth a play. You soon get used to the small faults and enjoy the game for its visuals and fast paced gameplay.

reviewText: This game is perfect proof that atmosphere isn't everything. While the suspenseful setting and uniquely dramatic score make for an interesting ride, sloppy parkour mechanics and an uninspired gameplay core will leave you bored within a couple hours. Amusing at first, the platforming and traps quickly become severe annoyances. While these parkour aspects are a decent take on an already sound system, it is not uncommon to find yourself dying repeatedly at the same point from missing a jump by mere pixels, solely because your leap was off by an attosecond or two. On top of that, the puzzle" aspect of the game is really nothing more than a speed bump to prevent you from shooting through the remarkably short game in under an hour. For each of these traps
date: you are virtually guaranteed to die the first attempt
recommended: and again nearly guaranteed to beat it on the second attempt. This is due to the puzzles not being puzzling in any sense
hoursPlayed: but more 'unforeseeable deathtraps' that are completely ineffective once you know of their location and MO.\n\nTLDR: If you can stand constantly revisiting the 3 minute gameover loading screen
voteText: and are not easily discouraged by excessive and unimaginative 'puzzles' that can be solved only by repetition (rather than wit and skill)
helpfulPercent: then the atmosphere and  combat of this game will be an enjoyable experience."

reviewText:
From the bright side: nice combination of 2D platformer and 3D environment, nice graphic...that all.
From cruel reality:
1)strange and unresponsive controls
2)really bad engine optimization: checkpoint loading tooks 4-8 seconds even with ssd drive - i understand when it's took time to load game in some rpgs or games with open world, because they working with massive amount of data, but for platformer without any complicated logic operating only with small scenes...well it's strange
3)finally it's plot and world design...it's AWFUL! Non realistic environment, heroes with schizophrenia signs (no, not Randall) taking idiotic decisions, unlogical behaviour (even in post apocalyptic world). As example (spoilers here):

-Soldiers flying around the city and shooting everything that moves except the zombies....wtf, what's the point spending fuel and ammo just for fun?
-Soldiers leaving heavily fortified base, and barricading on some kind of factory with one diesel generator. Omg, why not to rebuild this awesome base?
-Soldiers chasing Randal and girl while there is outbreak in their base. What problem is bigger: man and girl trying to escape or horde of zombies trying to kill you and ruin your base? Developers thinks that the problem is the girl....well...
-Randal deciding to stop transmission just by switching off controller ...Ok, you can't blow up radio tower or generator, but why not just slash damn controller with axe? Oh i forget, it was covert operation tssss.
-Stupid world with buildings looking and collapsing like they staying 20-30 years without humans....but there is only 60 days passed. Moreover, while the buildings is falling apart into pieces - there is electricity in town and portable generators is still working! Infinite fuel cheat perhaps..
-Ending...it's not heroic, not meaningful, not logical.Why just stay and watch: oh they all died...well i will die too" - great."

reviewText: It's got neat graphics, and nice gameplay ideas. Sadly, the playability isn't half as good as it should be and the story is really thin.\nWhile you try certain parts over and over again, either because you missed a tiny, inconspicuous object that you could have shot, or because the game lets you fail randomly half of the time even though you did exactly the same, you're getting telled a little background story that is a mix of all major zombie apocalypse clichés and a tiny twist that you can guess after the first two steps the main character has taken.\nThe game is not completely bad, but sadly, it is more bad than good. It could have been more.

reviewText:
Honestly, it's a short puzzle game with a story and zombies. The puzzles are rarely very challenging, most often involving dying 3-4 times until figuring out what you're supposed to be doing in the first place. It's interesting, and looks nice (not great,) but it feels like there should have been more.

I don't mean RPG elements or skill growth or any of that. Just more content. If you're going to have a basic game with basic mechanics, you need to have some length to it. The story was alright, but not the sort that leaves a lasting impact.

If you're reeeeally into zombie games and need a zombie platformer, then grab it on sale. But I'm glad I didn't pay more than $5 for this.

reviewText: This game would have been at most mediocre if the developers hadn't decided to stop developing halfway through and let their five-year-olds take over. This game is such a broken, glitchy mess, I'm absolutely certain no one playtested it. I encountered so many bugs during my time with it, I thought I had wound up in the Amazon Rainforest. Turns out I was just playing an awful game. One time, I respawned and my character just spun in circles repeatedly until a guard shot him to death. Another time, I swung my axe and it got stuck in the middle of the air, and my character crumpled into a depressing little ball that probably never got any love from his parents or any other human being in his sad, pathetic life, and blood shot out of his back, and then I died. Oh, but my favorite part is the length of time it takes for you to press a button. They may as well have given you elevator music to listen to at that point, because it feels as if you're riding a hotel elevator that never finds its destination. Just like how this game never finds its destination. Maybe the entire game is just an allegory for life and how we human beings are just miniscule pieces of star dust in the grand scheme of things, whose lives ultimately don't mean anything. But I don't think five-year-olds have the capacity to construct something so compelling. Lord only knows why I actually finished this game. There is a section at the very end that has you running from guards while your character lolls around like a reetarded puppet, and I swear to you if you make it through that without having an aneurysm, I will give you $100. My favorite part is how every achievement is named after a popular song from previous generations. If it were 2007, I'd be dying from laughter. This is one of the worst games I have ever played.

reviewText:
Warning: Although I do recommend this game, I feel that the game isn't worth the money at full price, but despite a lot of bad things about the game, I still could enjoy it. I can't guarantee that you'll enjoy it even if you are a platformer fan and like the Zombie Theme.

Let's start with the good things, the developers did a good job in making a zombie-apocalypse atmosphere, and especially in the beginning you feel like a lone survivor, just barely escaping the horde, with your Ezio-Like Climb skills.
You have very low health and run fast out of stamina (used for climbing and mainly fighting), making combat challenging and because if you mess up the horde will get you and just makes sense in these kind of games.
A big point about positives is the graphics, the game looks nice and the 2.5 D style makes this game feel more alive, defintly adds up to the atmosphere and seems to be what took most of the budged than developing this game sadly.
This difficulty builds up through the game to the point where at some points you have to time every single action near perfect to progress, which felt very frustrating and unnecessary, but this kind of difficulty is a lot of platformers, so it's really up to you whether that's a good or bad thing.
While the story and the voice lines are very generic as is the main character in the beginning, there is actually some good character development in the game and the ending was supinely satisfying, but didn't excuse the rest of the game.

It didn't excuse the frustrating dying over and over again scenarios, where I had no clue what to do or because of the inconsistent length of between the checkpoints, not to mention that the game doesn't always load the latest checkpoint you left. Also controls are unresponsive, as in I have to hammer a button, and the game wouldn't respond to first one or two button presses, mouse senility is off the charts and not in-game changeable. Not to mention the game can crash a few times, but due to the checkpoints, it is for most people irrelevant.
On certain level I want to comment on is the rat’s labyrinth, it's a fairly long level, without the great atmosphere and with generic platforming the rest of the game has and completely unreliable to the rest of the game, in case you come past this level don't be discouraged if you enjoyed the zombie-apocalypse atmosphere, it will come back

So do I recommend this? Well I do because this game is enjoyable, but there are a lot of problems this game has and if you aren't willing to except these problems and want to some zombie-apocalypse atmosphere, than don't get it.

reviewText: Frustrating mechanics. Laughably bad VA. Lackluster story. reviewText: Excellent game so far, my only issue with it is I've read (and feel) it's not gonna last long, I reckon less than 5hours on one playthfough (could be wrong, I'll update as necessary). As for the game itself, the production and polish is top notch, it is also  more varied then first appears. It could be considered as a Shadow Complex with zombies but more forgiving on death, more easier to play and more brain power required (you can't shoot your way through every situation.) Aside from platforming there are push / switch puzzles as well as a few ways to get pass the zombies such as whistling them to their demise or bringing them together to jump over them as well as collectables and secrets to be found. Overall 8-9/10 (considering if it turns out to be less than 5hrs gameplay I only paid £2.50 for it which is more than fair in that situation).

reviewText:
Well Microsoft scored points right off the bat for not using GFWL for this game.
Deadlight was a fun and engaging little platformer with a very rich atmosphere and dark environment. The controls are tight and the average zombie encounter gives you a fight or flight option with flight usually being the best course of action. The graphics and artwork of a destroyed post apocalyptic Seattle were stunning and the character development and pacing are well done. My only beef was with the puzzle elements of the game, being rudimentary and annoying to the point where they just felt like they were holding up the real gameplay and story progression.(Ratman I'm looking at you)
The nightmare mode as a reward for finishing doesn't offer much in the way of replayability but overall the game is worth picking up for the single playthrough.

I would recommend this game at around a $4-$6 price point.
