reviewText:
Bit mixed feelings about this game. It's not a bad game but too many flaws and problems made the initial amazing impression turn to a frown by the end.

Graphically its amazing, i really love the artstyle and how you view the world, the cutscenes are very stylistic but could use a few more frames in the animation. While the backgrounds aren't as amazing as in Trine 1&2 they are masterfully lit and really look great all the time. Those with an artistic interest would probably enjoy it a lot because of the environments.

The gameplay is similar to Another World and Prince of Persia, two very old games. This isnt a problem and works quite well most of the time, the biggest gripe I have is that sometimes jumping works fine to get past, other times you get stuck and die, melee doesnt connect, they manage to grab you in the middle of a swing or sometimes they just dont wanna fall down, its somewhat inconsistent and feels unfair rather than challenging.

This is the same through the whole game, some jumps are somewhat hard to see, some things are trial and error until you get it right. Most of the checkpoints are close so you wont have to replay much when you die, but the last section of the game is long and if you make a mistake you die and have to replay it all. Its not hard, but trial and error until you memorize that ♥♥♥♥.

The story could be better, the biggest flaw is in the writing and it suffers somewhat of the your father the king" syndrome. It could be so much better with some work

reviewText:
Deadlight is not worth playing. The platforming is incompetent, the combat is a buggy disaster, and the story is a transparent, mewling mess.

The premise is your standard biteception fare: zombies take over, survivors come down with a case of interminable douchiness, world goes to hell. You play a fellow named Randall Wayne, some random sod searching for his family months after the end of civilization. The story rarely meets anything resembling coherence, constantly pushing the boundaries of plausibility. Gentle helicopter crashes? Check. Man outrunning a hail of bullets? Check. Insane scientist calling the zombie plague the heaven we've all been awaiting? Check. You'll have predicted the outcome of the story before you finish the first area of the game, but the game doesn't miss an opportunity to hammer you with every trope it can find before you finally reach the punchline. It doesn't even have a consistent presentation: the story is told largely through comic-book-noir cutscenes, which clash amusingly with the gameplay's generic realistic-3D look.

On the gameplay side, Deadlight is basically a 2D platformer with 3D backgrounds used to the worst possible effect. You'll often be left wondering whether items are in the foreground or background -- sometimes you'll jump at something which isn't there, and other times you'll bounce off an object you thought was out of reach. The platforming itself fails to offer challenge in any sense beyond the omnipresent bugs. You will rarely have more than 1 route, there are basically no puzzles to solve, and the game never pressures you to make tough maneuvers. You'll fall to your death repeatedly, however, because the game sometimes just forgets to grab ledges or just won't turn around without running halfway across the screen. The controls are generally unresponsive and unwieldy. The game actively prevents meeting that platforming zen by pulling you to a complete stop any time you do anything. Catch a climbing line midair? You'll be watching a 3-second animation while Randall grabs onto it, then come to a complete stop and slowly crawl from one side of the line to the other. Sometimes, Randall will teleport about because the game can't even decide where you are. He will hang from invisible ledges or be unable to jump. If you fall the wrong place, you can get completely stuck and have to restart the scene entirely.

Combat, however, is a whole 'nother level. Zombies attack from the background, so you never know when you can hit them and when you can't. Sometimes, they'll even fall back from the foreground into the background, and you're left swinging at nothing until it re-emerges on top of Randall and immediately grapples. The meeting of Randall and zombie is never remotely clean, often leaving Randall struggling with air and a zombie flailing wildly behind him. Using anything but the heavy axe attack is pointless because Randall will otherwise teleport through enemies, failing to hit them, or push enemies from the ground back onto their feet. The most joy you'll get out of it is laughing at the utter absurdity of it.

To summarize, Deadlight is not worth the time to play, let alone the cash. The combat is poor, the platforming is poor, the story is poor, the presentation is dodgy, and it's just not fun.

reviewText: I really wanted to like this game. Unfortunately, there is a lot of frustration included with this sometimes entertaining game. This is one of the best looking 2.5d game I've seen. It's up there with Trine 2 and Insanely Twisted Shadow Planet. It looks very realistic. The backgrounds are lively and there's always lots of stuff going on.  The voice actor for the grizzled main character did a good job. This game's best feature is its style. That's about all it has going for it, though. The actual gameplay is thin. Standard platforming. Jump here, climb that. Run. Duck. Wail away on a zombie. It can be entertaining, but nothing that hasn't been done before. The controls are decent for most of the scenarios encountered in the game, but at times when quick precision is necessary, the  game falls flat on its face. At times the pace of the game grinds down to a screeching halt as parts need to be played over and over and over again due to the controls not responding properly. There's also other times where you have a split second to react to things or else death. Sometimes there's no way to know what exactly is being asked until dying and restarting the section again.  The very ending of the game nicely encapsulates all the shortcomings I've just listed. I see promise from the developers, but this game just does too many things poorly to recommend.

reviewText: Design more than trumps mood or story. That is the story of Deadlight, however, design is its weakest part. Deadlight is a moody puzzle action adventure where... yet again the world is taken over by zombies. There's a back story abot the character that is muddled in weird flashbacks and diary pages. You never get a sense of why you are being told this boring story. But the pay off is the ending (somewhat). The game concludes very satsfactorily. Platforming and the puzzles are incredibly tedious and can be frustrating. Be prepared to die again... and again simply becaus your character is as slow as a lumbering tractor.

reviewText:
I'd recommend Deadlight if you like trial and error games or games that constantly bug out on you or repeatedly crash to desktop when you try and pause them (five times). For a bonus do you like animated cut scenes that don't fit in with the asthetic of the game? Deadlight has you covered. Do you like poor voice acting? Deadlight has you covered.

Nice idea, poorly executed.

reviewText: Excellent game so far, my only issue with it is I've read (and feel) it's not gonna last long, I reckon less than 5hours on one playthfough (could be wrong, I'll update as necessary). As for the game itself, the production and polish is top notch, it is also  more varied then first appears. It could be considered as a Shadow Complex with zombies but more forgiving on death, more easier to play and more brain power required (you can't shoot your way through every situation.) Aside from platforming there are push / switch puzzles as well as a few ways to get pass the zombies such as whistling them to their demise or bringing them together to jump over them as well as collectables and secrets to be found. Overall 8-9/10 (considering if it turns out to be less than 5hrs gameplay I only paid £2.50 for it which is more than fair in that situation).

reviewText:
Warning: Although I do recommend this game, I feel that the game isn't worth the money at full price, but despite a lot of bad things about the game, I still could enjoy it. I can't guarantee that you'll enjoy it even if you are a platformer fan and like the Zombie Theme.

Let's start with the good things, the developers did a good job in making a zombie-apocalypse atmosphere, and especially in the beginning you feel like a lone survivor, just barely escaping the horde, with your Ezio-Like Climb skills.
You have very low health and run fast out of stamina (used for climbing and mainly fighting), making combat challenging and because if you mess up the horde will get you and just makes sense in these kind of games.
A big point about positives is the graphics, the game looks nice and the 2.5 D style makes this game feel more alive, defintly adds up to the atmosphere and seems to be what took most of the budged than developing this game sadly.
This difficulty builds up through the game to the point where at some points you have to time every single action near perfect to progress, which felt very frustrating and unnecessary, but this kind of difficulty is a lot of platformers, so it's really up to you whether that's a good or bad thing.
While the story and the voice lines are very generic as is the main character in the beginning, there is actually some good character development in the game and the ending was supinely satisfying, but didn't excuse the rest of the game.

It didn't excuse the frustrating dying over and over again scenarios, where I had no clue what to do or because of the inconsistent length of between the checkpoints, not to mention that the game doesn't always load the latest checkpoint you left. Also controls are unresponsive, as in I have to hammer a button, and the game wouldn't respond to first one or two button presses, mouse senility is off the charts and not in-game changeable. Not to mention the game can crash a few times, but due to the checkpoints, it is for most people irrelevant.
On certain level I want to comment on is the rat’s labyrinth, it's a fairly long level, without the great atmosphere and with generic platforming the rest of the game has and completely unreliable to the rest of the game, in case you come past this level don't be discouraged if you enjoyed the zombie-apocalypse atmosphere, it will come back

So do I recommend this? Well I do because this game is enjoyable, but there are a lot of problems this game has and if you aren't willing to except these problems and want to some zombie-apocalypse atmosphere, than don't get it.

reviewText:
Second of my apocalyptic double tonight is 'Deadlight'

A 80's style and setting, old school platformer very similar to the original Prince of Persia and Another World/Flashback and the more modern Limbo.
So we have a side scrolling 2D platformer set in a very serious very bleak setting. It paints a grim zombie infested world with a direct nod to George Romero's earlier dead trilogy. There's no comedy here. And the sheer level of detail in the gorgeous visuals really really hit home the hopelesness of it all. The backgrounds are beautifully drawn and animated. The soundtrack and ambient effects are top notch too. A really fantastic atmophere it all creates.

Some nice collectibles to be found also. And there a full set of making of videos and early artwork. Lots of 80's stuff and an explanation of why the game was set in the 80's :) Worth looking through it if you buy the game.

I totally recommend it!

PS all of the achievements are named after hit songs from the 80's :)

reviewText:
Deadlight is a sidescrolling survival horror/puzzle game with nice presentation value, mostly solid controls, and a tendency to take itself just a bit too seriously in the story department.

Let me clarify: for its price, this isn't a bad title by any means. The above strengths make up for the shortcomings well enough. It's just that when you have a game with a setup this relatively simple, you'd expect it to surprise you in at least a few ways. Portal did this with a pitch-black sense of humor that blended seamlessly with a frighteningly sterile, claustrophobic atmosphere. Unfortunately, while the atmosphere is certainly there, there are a few things that really hamper the experience its trying to create.

The Abe's Odysee style sidescrolling makes for some great visuals, as the interplay of the background and foreground does a lot to enhance the otherwise banal sight of zombies wandering around the broken urban landscape. Sadly this leads to a bit of frustration when you can't tell if a zombie is within axing range or just outside, and you'll burn up your  stamina or bullets really fast swinging or shooting frantically at the so-called Shadow" only to find that he'll still get ahold of you. Furthermore
date: there is some highlighting of climbable surfaces
hoursPlayed: so often of times you'll die in the same space over and over only to find there was a wire or pipe you could have latched onto. It gets even worse when the game reflex-tests you by sliding down a hill or chasing you through the busy streets
voteText: all the while tripping over piles of cardboard boxes you had no idea were in your way to begin with and wondering why you couldn't just take the staircase instead of hopping from handrail to handrail like an Assassin's Creed character. A few times I walked by a zombie trapped in a car and was a little disapointed that he couldnt reach me from where he was

reviewText:
This game brings a new edge to the zombie apocalypse genre. As a platform game it is very rich in detail and deep in story. I would compare it to the likes of Trine but of course with a more realistic feel.

Although the puzzles in the game are not that difficult, it keeps you entertained by occasionally requiring the use of one of your abilities, like shouting to get attention from zombies, to get past particular parts. Some parts are fast paced where you don't stop to kill zombies whereas others are take it slow and search to find the secrets of each stage. Which are sometimes interestingly hidden. This brings back memories of the old platform games from the 90s.

The controls are simple and not overly complex which gets you into the game very fast. You really only need your movement and action keys of swinging an axe or interacting with an object. Though of course you can shoot the different guns and slingshots that you get and as previously mentioned get the attention of people through the shout key. The stamina bar is a nice addition and adds to the realism of the game that swinging an axe at zombies does make you tired! So you have to be careful not to overdo it and back off as required.

I played this with keyboard and mouse but you can play with the controller also, and I think it would make an excellant relax on the sofa game.

A highly recommended game from me all around.

reviewText:
As a beta tester I couldn't enjoy this game as much as I would have liked because the developers were undoubtably lazy in polishing the mechanics of this game.

First off, the hit detection for melee is broken, you can't hit a zombie that's a centimeter into the background despite performing a horizontal swing that clearly would've connected, zombies have no problems attacking you from the background however.
It also randomly decides not to hit zombies who are perfectly in range of getting hit. Zombies have no problem at all with hitting you while you're at least a half meter out of their range or taking a swing at you when you're prone on the floor, said swing being performed at shoulder height and somehow manages to hit a target a whole meter below that.
Getting grabbed by a zombie is almost always a death sentence if there are other zombies nearby as it is impossible to push multiple zombies away, they'll pass through others as if they were ghosts, giving you no option of crowd control or getting out of a bad situation, this also didn't make the areas with infinitely spawning zombies any easier. If the whole point of the game was meant to evade the zombies at all cost, why even bother giving the broken option of trying to fight them off in melee?

The controls sometimes decide to do whatever they feel like, swinging back and forth over a fence instead of dropping down and sometimes climbing back up a ledge I'm trying to climb down.

Certain areas of the game were very annoying as it required you to do things in a very fluid and nigh-perfectly executed and predetermined manner. One area in particular had a warehouse that would collapse bit by bit, I was stuck on this area for far too long because the game did not like me trying to be too fast by performing a running jump over a pit and continuing to run, doing this would result in the final piece of debris killing me a mere centimeter away from the next segment. Instead the game forced you to make a normal jump over the pit and then sprint in order to clear this area. Stupid.

The main character is supposedly a park warden, who can't swim, not only can he not swim but he also sinks like a rock straight to the bottom where he will drown standing almost immediately. This did not help with my immersion into the game at all as it was a poor excuse to have some water based obstacles in the game.

I'm not surprised none of my friends bothered playing this game to the end, all of them appear to have stopped playing at the exact same spot as well, I wonder why.

reviewText:
Eh. It was...disappointing.

The good:
Very atmospheric and bleak. Absolutely amazing setting.
Interesting game ideas.
The whole idea that you cannot mow down crowds of zombies and can be overwhelmed by 3 or 4 is great, too.

Then the rest is...meh. It relies so much on precision platforming you can't do with the super loose controls. There's a story, but it never does much with it. The platforming itself, even if it was tighter, would be meh at best. It's so much potential with so much /meh/.

Oh, and it's a little over 3 hours long and you die repeatedly for little reason. Did you mean to jump, but instead dropped into 3 zombies? RIP you.

reviewText:
I got this game as part of a Humble Bundle, and boy oh boy do I recommend steering clear of it. I'm forcing myself to finish it out of some misplaced desire to complete it, but I wish I had never started.

First, the good: the game looks nice. It has a good aesthetic, and the backgrounds and environments make this 2.5D sidescroller pretty to look at. This is where my praise ends.

Despite how polished and professional the game LOOKS, nearly everything else is crap. The gameplay is a rather tired form of puzzle platformer that's been done time and time again by games like Limbo and the original Prince of Persia. However, the Puzzles" are mediocre
date: usually involving activating whatever highlighted item happens to be in the room with you. Similarly
hoursPlayed: due to sloppy controls

reviewText: Deadlight is a good game I enjoyed it immensely. It's a puzzle platformer/ zombie game. I never imagined that a zombie setting would fit well with a platformer, you would think that the platforming would take away from the creepy zombie vibe, but it actually comes across quite nicely. The aesthetics are wonderfull with crumbling hotels, underground sewers, and a plague filled hospital. The weakest part of the game for me would be the story but even that  ended well, and if you actually read Randall's diary you may apreciate it much more. The gameplay is solid and fun while being very linear. The biggest complaint I've been hearing about this game is the clunky control's and I would have to agree somewhat. The controls are clunky but I feel that it suits its purpose. So in the end DeadLight is  fun platformer that has a great aesthetic, pretty good story, and ok gameplay, I would recommend to fans of the puzzle/platformer and zombie genre.

reviewText:
Good:
Really nice visuals, and a decent story.

Bad:
Hard to tell what's in the background as opposed to your current plane. It's a 2D game but the enemies sometimes come from the background and it's hard to tell at what point you can hit them. The gun combat is OK, but the melee is very poor, the hit detection seems to be a bit off much of the time. Occasionally unresponsive controls. Some cheesy deaths from the environment that can only be avoided if you've already tried it once.

Conclusion:
I'd give it a 5/10 at full price, but if you can get it for 5 bucks of less i'd probably bump it up to a 6/10. It had potential if they only tightened up the combat and made the background and foreground a little more distinctive.

reviewText: I have to write a review before I lose my absolute anger with this game. The storyline is good, but in order to fully understand it you have to read a 60 page diary of this guys life. But that's not the worst part. The worst part is that the gameplay is tedious as ♥♥♥♥. It's freerunning parkour, but you have to be exactly in the right area, and for many parts of the game, at exactly the right time. And in order to do this, you have to die multiple times just to get passed one scene. If there's a helicopter chasing you, you die if you lose a second of running. Also, I have my settings for this game on the lowest possible, and yet I get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ framerate at certain areas, and it will freeze up randomly, which also sucks during chase scenes where one second will kill you. Why does a game with crappy drawn out graphics require so much RAM just to run? You're better off watching someone play this on YouTube, or better yet reading about it on wikipedia. This game would be much better as a novel, and is no where near worth the money.

reviewText:
Pros
- Pretty good character animation.
- The guns (though used sparingly) feel nice and are satisfying.
- Environments looked pretty nice, y'know, as far the whole post-apocalypse thing goes.
- Puzzle sections aren't too bad, provided you aren't getting pressured by something. (See Con #4)

Cons
- Clunky movement in tight spaces and in combat
- Mostly poor voice acting
- A pretty short and fairly anti-climactic final level with a really dull twist ending with a side of annoying supporting character whining at you. Her actions in the last cutscene actually infuriated me, tbh.
- Any tense set piece (especially toward the end) can easily loose its grip when you die from missing a small environment clue or Randall not drawing his gun fast enough.
- Can't kill zombies approaching you from the background until they're right on top of you, even though you have a gun.
- Wanna jump or swing your axe in a certain direction? Just point one way and press the button you want and Randall will just do it in the opposite direction you wanted him to.
- The last half of the game in general was chalk full of frustrating little things overall (and that's pretty much everything I mentioned above).

That about sums it up. This is the first game I actually felt strongly enough to write a negative review about for the game itself, and not a botched port job.

reviewText: I've heard this game getting some negative attention, but having gotten to Act 3, I can tell you it is fairly well undeserved. There are a couple minor control issues, mostly centered around climbing quickly while being chased by helicopters, lol, but outside of that, the game controls are fairly seamless. The game itself is fun as hell. It's a 2-D scroller with a 3-D background which looks really cool in a sort of Apocalyptic Noire fashion. The gameplay itself is fun. You get weapons sparingly and always need to make decision regarding how you are going to deal with the zombies (or Shadows as they are called in this game). You have a stamina bar which is drained when running or engaging in melee combat. You have a very limited amount of bullets for any guns you find. You are however quite acrobatic, and running, jumping, diving, and rolling are equally important from a tactical standpoint. There are also som cool trap sequences, and in many parts, you can use the environment to your advantage as well.\nFinally, the story is also really quite interesting, and unlike most games, the secrets" (aka hidden objects) are very easy to find
date: although with the undead on your tail
recommended: you may not have time to grab them
hoursPlayed: lol\n\nI think this is a definite must own. It really is a very good game in my opinion."

reviewText: Tried to enjoy this game because the art style and environment is amazing, but unfortunately the game is ruined by horrible controls and a boring, cliche story. Te elaborate on the controls; this game basically expects you to have very precise movements in order to jump and land on obstacles and to dodge traps and run from zombies. However, the movement is very clunky, and every action you perform seems to have such a delay that finding the correct timing is more or less a combination of luck and tedious trial and error. Your character can either jump 6 inches straight up, or 10 feet diagonally, with no inbetween. Trying to jump and grab a platform straight above your head is a nightmare because either you're off by an inch and will miss and have to retry until you get lucky and find a sweet spot, or you will accidentally jump at an angle you go 10 feet too far and fall to your death. As for the story it has all the typical zombie cliches that we've all seen before.  Save yourself some time and frustration and give this game a pass.

reviewText:
One of the best XBLA titles of 2012!

No modern communications devices (set in 1986), so the sense of dread and fear and alone is very real. Somewhat of a L4D style game, but you progress more effectively and safely by running, jumping, rolling, and generally avoiding zombies altogether.

Storyline is very good, and feels genuine. Aesthetically, it's gorgeous, with the protagonist silhouetted in a darkened foreground running for his life in a crumbled, mutilated Seattle (my home, no less).

Minimal, but engaging, and the ending is not necessary predictable.

reviewText:
I'm not really a fan of zombies or zombie games. They've never really scared me and they're a dime a dozen these days. So when I picked this up during a Humble Bundle sale for really cheap, I wasn't expecting much. However, this game surpassed my expectations and turned out to be one of the best indie games included in the bundle.

Story:The game takes place in Seattle in 1986 after the outbreak of a virus that has resurrected the dead and turned them into zombies. You assume the role of Randall Wayne, a park ranger and survivor of the virus who is on his way to the last remaining safe point in hopes of finding his wife and daughter.

Gameplay:Deadlight combines elements of a platforming, puzzle solving and horror. You're always encouraged to run away from the zombies you encounter unless you have no other option. You're only armed with an axe, but as you progress through the game you'll come across a handgun and a shotgun. Ammunition is limited though, so you should only use when it's necessary. The meat of this game is the platforming. It makes good use of parkour, which is the best part about this game in my opinion. The game is very linear, but very fun to play. Included are several things to collect, which makes the experience more fulfilling as it offers something in addition to just playing through each level and progressing through the story. There's also an additional mode called Nightmare Mode"
date: which is basically the same as the main story except you're not allowed to die. If you die in Nightmare Mode
recommended: then you must restart from the very beginning.\n\nNegatives:The only negative for this game is it's length. It took me less than 7 hours to complete 100%. That's not always a bad thing. Not every game has to be 20 hours or 40 hours long. I just think $15 is a bit much to ask for a game that's so short. Sure
hoursPlayed: you could play Nightmare Mode. I'm sure that would add lots of time
voteText: but it's just more of the same on a much harder difficulty and doesn't really add anything new.\n\nConclusion:Overall
helpfulPercent: I'd recommend this game to anyone that's a fan of platformers or zombie games. I'm not even a fan of zombies
votesHelpful: but I still really enjoyed this game. The story is good and the gameplay is great. It's well worth buying
votesTotal: but because of it's short length
votesFunny: I'd suggest waiting for it to go on sale."

reviewText:
Warning: Although I do recommend this game, I feel that the game isn't worth the money at full price, but despite a lot of bad things about the game, I still could enjoy it. I can't guarantee that you'll enjoy it even if you are a platformer fan and like the Zombie Theme.

Let's start with the good things, the developers did a good job in making a zombie-apocalypse atmosphere, and especially in the beginning you feel like a lone survivor, just barely escaping the horde, with your Ezio-Like Climb skills.
You have very low health and run fast out of stamina (used for climbing and mainly fighting), making combat challenging and because if you mess up the horde will get you and just makes sense in these kind of games.
A big point about positives is the graphics, the game looks nice and the 2.5 D style makes this game feel more alive, defintly adds up to the atmosphere and seems to be what took most of the budged than developing this game sadly.
This difficulty builds up through the game to the point where at some points you have to time every single action near perfect to progress, which felt very frustrating and unnecessary, but this kind of difficulty is a lot of platformers, so it's really up to you whether that's a good or bad thing.
While the story and the voice lines are very generic as is the main character in the beginning, there is actually some good character development in the game and the ending was supinely satisfying, but didn't excuse the rest of the game.

It didn't excuse the frustrating dying over and over again scenarios, where I had no clue what to do or because of the inconsistent length of between the checkpoints, not to mention that the game doesn't always load the latest checkpoint you left. Also controls are unresponsive, as in I have to hammer a button, and the game wouldn't respond to first one or two button presses, mouse senility is off the charts and not in-game changeable. Not to mention the game can crash a few times, but due to the checkpoints, it is for most people irrelevant.
On certain level I want to comment on is the rat’s labyrinth, it's a fairly long level, without the great atmosphere and with generic platforming the rest of the game has and completely unreliable to the rest of the game, in case you come past this level don't be discouraged if you enjoyed the zombie-apocalypse atmosphere, it will come back

So do I recommend this? Well I do because this game is enjoyable, but there are a lot of problems this game has and if you aren't willing to except these problems and want to some zombie-apocalypse atmosphere, than don't get it.

reviewText: Tried to enjoy this game because the art style and environment is amazing, but unfortunately the game is ruined by horrible controls and a boring, cliche story. Te elaborate on the controls; this game basically expects you to have very precise movements in order to jump and land on obstacles and to dodge traps and run from zombies. However, the movement is very clunky, and every action you perform seems to have such a delay that finding the correct timing is more or less a combination of luck and tedious trial and error. Your character can either jump 6 inches straight up, or 10 feet diagonally, with no inbetween. Trying to jump and grab a platform straight above your head is a nightmare because either you're off by an inch and will miss and have to retry until you get lucky and find a sweet spot, or you will accidentally jump at an angle you go 10 feet too far and fall to your death. As for the story it has all the typical zombie cliches that we've all seen before.  Save yourself some time and frustration and give this game a pass.

Yet another crap game chasing a slice of the zombie money pie.

You play as Gruff McNopersonality, a survivor of the zombie apocolypse whose skills include swinging axes ineffectually and escaping certain death courtesy of poorly written deus ex machinas. Buy Limbo instead.

reviewText:
Deadlight is another one of Microsoft Studio's side-scolling platformer games that tells us the story of Randall Wayne, and his determination to save his friends from the aftermath of a zombie apocalypse. It pretty similar to a few games like LIMBO, in terms of the platforming, and This War is Mine in terms of the visuals. The story was extremely short, let's say about 3-4 hours, but I won't speak against that because even though this game has its positives, there are also as many negatives in it, and that makes me want to just drop the game at any moment.

The visuals - Out of everything else in the game, this is what stood out the most. Grim, dark, and creepy - an appropriate setting for a game like this. The artwork is, as always, brilliant. To keep to the tone of the game, it won't be colourful (obviously). It probably draws inspiration from LIMBO. The cinematics are pretty similar to the artwork you'd see in The Walking Dead comic books.

The story - It is extremely short, but I felt it was good enough for me to be able to enjoy it. But it wasn't exactly immersive. There was not much character development, mostly only focusing on your main character,  and the start of the game feels like you're playing a game that's halfway done. Personally, as the game progressed, I questioned myself as to why I should give a damn about a bunch of characters I couldn't know about a bit more. It just felt inadequate.

The gameplay - Deadlight has its fair share of puzzles, and I'd say they're actually pretty ... not nice. Certain objects just go unnoticed, you just can't see them. It's frustrating. And the same thing could be said about the platforming. It's utterly maddening that you have to jump from Point A to Point B without having to know you'll probably die while doing it ... and you actually will (I literally stopped playing it once, because it was really rustling my feathers). Oh, and it's a mediocre port.

The verdict - I'd say that the game honestly did not live up to its expectations for me. I got it with full intentions that it would be one of the best games I've played, but nah. It's got a nice story, but terrible gameplay. I've also had issues with its bugs, too, as the cinematics would lose sound, so I'd feel like I'm watching a silent movie. Thank God for subtitles. All in all, I'd say get the game strictly when it is on sale. Would I recommend it to platform-lovers? No. What about story-oriented players? Maybe, maybe not (Mostly a no). But I will tell you this - Deadlight is very much forgettable.

reviewText:
I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.

One Hour Reviews #43 - Deadlight

I'll start by saying I love the art style in Deadlight.  This is definitely the strong point of the game.  The entire game is a 2D side scroller, but the attention to detail is really well done.

Unlike other zombie games I've played, there isn't as much of an emphasis on combat in this game.  It's really more about using your parkour skills to keep finding a way forward.  More often than not I was running from zombies because it's easier to run than to fight.  This changes somewhat when you eventually get a gun, but even then your bullets are limited.

The game plays like an adventure game, where the main character Randall serving as narrator.  You progress through levels, and in between you'll get a little animated comic book sequence that tells more of the overall story.  You can also find pieces of Randall's diary along the way which also fill in gaps in the story.

Don't expect any kind of an open world here.  The gameplay is completely linear.  If you die you'll go back to your last checkpoint.  There's no visual cue as to where the checkpoints are, but there seem to be a lot of them.  I never had to repeat more than a minute or two of gameplay in any of the deaths I had.

In some ways this is a strange game because as a zombie game I wasn't that impressed with it.  As an adventure game the story is okay, but not what I would consider the strong point of the game.  It's the platforming elements where the game stood out for me, which I was not expecting going in to this.

I'm a little lukewarm about paying the full $15 for it, so I'd recommend maybe waiting for this to go on sale.  As it happens right now it's 75% off, so for just under $4 it's definitely worth picking up.  Regardless of the price, I had fun with the game and really enjoyed the art, so I can recommend it based on these strengths.

reviewText:
Deadlight shows a lot of potential, especially early on. It's a tense, dark side scrolling platform with a great art style and wonderful attention to detail.

Sadly this only lasts for the first Act. Eventually the ideas ran out and the cohesive world building and fourth wall are broken for no apparent reason. Instant kill traps for no good reason, forced combat situations, cliche story, and trial and error fill up the rest of the remaining two acts.

I'll explain a bit more about the trial and error as that is what truly causes this game to deserve a thumbs down. This is a game that will make you want to throw a controller/smash a keyboard. I'm fine with tough platformers, but not if the problem is the controls. The tight controls from the begining of the game do not hold up to the advanced we put this death trap ridden jungle gym of a house falling apart just becuase" sections throughout the game.

reviewText: I found the play style quite similar to Trine (which i love but who doesnt?) in its puzzles, the game looks good and the story is ok although the game is very short and it feels like there are alot of unanswered questions at the end but that might be because i didnt bother reading all the pages from his diaries that you find all over. I really only have two complaints about the game and that is how short it is, i completed it in 3 hours but there is a nightmare mode which i assume is just playing it at a higher difficulty. My other complaint is the keymapping for keyboard, it is obvious that the game is made to play with a controller as some moves are quite hard to do on the keyboard such as the tumble (you need to hold shift+ctrl+A(or)B) and there is no way to remap the keys to my knowledge. But all in all great game but 12 euro seems a bit pricey for 3 hours of just doing the campaign once but if you think about it going to the cinema costs about the same :P so go ahead and get it.

reviewText:
It's short, I beat the story in under 5 hours. Once the story is complete it unlocks knightmare mode.
Going through on knightmare, completing the game 100% and unlocking achievements will add additional replay value.

The story itself isn't terrible, but it's nothing special either.
Gameplay is the highlight of this game, but can sometimes be frustrating. Simple controls don't respond every so often making your character miss a jump, not turning properly to hit a zombie, resulting in death or losing hp.

I got the game on sale for $3 so I would have to recommend for that price, however buying the game full price I would not recommend.

reviewText:
Note: I played through the whole game before actually getting in Steam, I don't even know why I bought it, compulsive spending I guess.

Overall Impressions

I expected this game to be better, first of all, there are a lot of issues are which are making the experience less enjoyable. I'll start with gameplay, the controls themselves are good, but the overall platforming feels slow and clunky, things easily blend in with the background and make it harder to see where you need to jump to.

Animations aren't so good when platforming too which makes the game feel even more awkward while jumping around. Sometimes you have to stop and carefully place your character right above an object (which takes time and zombies are almost always following you)  in order to jump and trigger a grabbing animation.

The shooting is kinda fun, despite the clunky aiming and platforming, the so-called game secrets" are simply obvious

reviewText:
Deadlight is a game where we take on the role of a survivor, Randall Wayne, as he searches for his family in an apocalyptic Seattle.

The sound and audio in Deadlight are phenomenal. Deadlight features a wonderful sountrack that fits each level perfectly. The voice acting in Deadlight is quite well done as well, though at times the narrative can be a little emotionless. There are no cutting or static issues with the audio in Deadlight. Deadlight delivers a wonderful experience through sound. 4.5/5

Visually Deadlight is stunning. Brilliant aesthetics and effects really bring this game to life. Deadlight is by far the most beautiful sidescroller game I have ever played. The textures are crisp, clean, and high quality. No texture clipping or inconsistencies were experienced. 5/5

Deadlight's story is well written. The story in Deadlight is both narrated through Randall's thoughts and read through his diary. The added depth to the story that comes from the reading of Randall's diary really gives the player insight into Randall's world. The story is full of tense moments and unexpected twists.  5/5

Mechanically Deadlight are well done, but not perfect. Deadlight features some environment interaction, though this is mostly limited to opening doors and solving puzzles. The movement in Deadlight is quite fun- being able to blast through levels as fast as possible, or taking it slow. The game has some issues with regards to keyboard controls, as it is difficult to make some jumps, though this is not really an issue. The gameplay can be a little iffy" at times
date: such as events not firing or forcing the player out of areas. No crashes were experienced.  3/5\n\nDeadlight is a game that takes place in a beautiful world
recommended: with amazing sounds and voice acting. The story in Deadlight is fantastically executed and deep. The game has very basic mechanics
hoursPlayed: despite this
voteText: the game is worth every penny.\n\nFinal numerical score 17.5/20 or 87%"

reviewText:
I can sum this up real quick for you as Zombie Prince of Persia. Prince of Zombies? Zombies of Seattle? Also, I mean the old Apple II one.

Deadlight is a 3D side-scrolling platformer with the same precise yet tanky controls from two decades ago. There's running and jumping and turning in place and stopping on a dime, and God help you if you flub a jump. You play Randall, a gravelly survivor of the zombie apocalypse who wishes he had half the gravitas as Bill. You must guide him as he mantles up and over the thousand fences, crates, and fire escapes of Seattle in search of his three survivor buddies and maybe his family? I dunno, I was too busy wrestling the terrible combat controls.

Melee in this game is awful, as it only functions a certain distance from your character. Any closer and you harmlessly shove enemies away instead of whacking them. It makes mobs of zombies a proper death sentence, but in a game like this where it's easy to miss one running jump and land in a pit of undead, it can get frustrating fast. The gun is more effective but your ammo is rather limited and headshots are a must. I tended to do a lot more running from fights, which the game seems to support and often expects anyway.

Do not buy into this one for the story, for it is terrible. The characters are incredibly one-dimensional and the writing is bad to the point of nonsense in some places. It is a pretty game however, in that lovingly-rendered hellscape sort of way. There's a lot of detail in the environments (so much so that it can obscure your path at times), and plenty of little collectibles hidden in out-of-the-way spots or obvious deathtraps. Looks to be about a 5-6 hour game, quicker if you don't bother looking for goodies. Decent playtime for the price, but the rough edges lead me to suggest a sale purchase if at all.

If you thought Prince of Persia needed a modern reboot with zombies and bad combat, by all means give it a try.

reviewText:
Oh Deadlight what happened? From a first glance you look like you tick all the boxes: a puzzle-platformer to the likes of Abe's Odyssey or Flashback in a shadowy, gritty zombie apocalypse! but instead you have clunky controls, horrendous dialogue, cliché story, obscure combat and an 80's setting that has no significance to... anything!

Turn the light out, it's dead in the water.

reviewText: OMG what can i say, totally blown away by this game, even though it is a side scrolling adventure which i tend to not like this game has impressed me from the start with great visuals, cool storyline and some very nice puzzles to navigate. Full price this game is worth a purchase, get it on sale and no brainer, go see for yourself i doubt you will be disapointed. 9/10

reviewText:
2D platformer like Trine. Except nowhere near as good. Plenty of issues with non-existent foreground/background differentiation, terrible deadpan voiceacting from The Rat, obstacle course gameplay with trial and error and annoying loads for every try, tedious and unnaturally cryptic dialogue from a NORMAL person who's trying to tell you critical mutually beneficial information, and just generally plodding pacing of the plot make this title Deadboring to play.

Oh yeah, and the criticisms about controls is true. Mostly, it's that it takes a second for your character to accelerate to a run properly, and your character needs to fully transition to a different stance (hanging/running/jumping) to accept a new context sensitive command. It usually results in difficulty in controlling distances of jumps, and a slippery feeling to the controls.

I gave up this game when The Rat tasks you to find his son, but refuses to return your axe and gun, even though he acknowledges the journey on the surface would be perilous... What? And instead of just walking with The Rat into the background platforms to get about, instead he follows you along catwalks while you complete an unnecessary obstacle course below, even though he's already acknowledged you. DOES HE WANT ME TO RESCUE HIS SON OR JUST ♥♥♥♥ AROUND?

This game's strongest point is its atmosphere and environment (except for how poorly it communicates what platforms/objects are reachable/usable/in the foreground). Unfortunately, because of how idiotic the characters are, it ruins any sense of immersion or belief, and there's really nothing more to play for.

reviewText: This game is awful. Terrible design. Terrible port. No play testing as far as I can tell. All your deaths result from unresponsive controls, poorly designed puzzles, and long character animations. Don't waste money on this game. One puzzle is literally impossible with mouse/keyboard as far as I can tell. Don't buy it. Don't buy anything from this dev. The end.
